DO NOT take the children to see this movie because you will ruin their childhood. Well yes because children are used to seeing a friendly, tender and pretty yellow bear. But in this movie you see the opposite. Now to finish this review: I DO NOT RECOMMEND YOU SEE THIS FILM BECAUSE IT IS HORRIBLE.

review_title: can't make a good horror movie without a famous character?
review_detailed_main: I can only associate this movie with the way the world is going. Downhill. Why do we have to convert the good things into bad things? I am not a Winnie the Pooh's fan but I just think the creators of this movie don't really have much creativity to create their own characters, so they get the rights to use these characters and twist the story to make it into a horror story, I wonder how many people would watch it if it is not because Winnie the Pooh is in the title. It is not that hard to twist a good story into a horror story, you have many of the characters, their background, the setting, it is just a quick way of doing a movie. What is next? Are we going to convert Woody and gang into villains just because they were tired of being put in the attic or kids not playing with them?

The outrage is more than justified over Winnie The Pooh: Blood And Honey, not because it blasphemes the sanctity of A. A. Milne's "beloved" Winnie The Pooh, but because they obliterated the possibility of making a great Winnie The Pooh horror movie by making this grotesquely BAD movie instead. Had this been directed by Alexandre Aja (the 2006 remake of The Hills Have Eyes), or Marcus Nispel (the 2003 remake of The Texas Chainsaw Massacre), the potential for a wildly disturbing and terrifying dark adult fable might have been achieved. An inexcusable missed opportunity. AND they're already making the sequel. Ugh, I feel damned for all eternity for having watched this.

I think every single person on this planet fully expected this movie to be horrible when it was first announced, so it should come as no surprise that it actually is. I watched it after seeing the extremely low imdb score, so I knew what to expect. This movie isnt even trying to be good. For starters, they didnt bother making pooh and piglet look like actual animals. They just look like fat men in costumes, and I actually like that. It makes them look even crazier. Yes the acting throughout is terrible, but the human characters are not supposed to be the main attraction of the show. Pooh and piglet are. I was a little disappointed that owl and rabbit didnt appear even though their characters were introduced in the beginning, while tiger isnt even in the movie at all. The movie actually managed to entertain me in ways modern hollywood movies dont, and that's why I gave it a quite generous score of 5/10. I heard a sequel has been announced. I WILL watch it.

So dumb. So good.

This is what it is, and it's proud to be just that.

If you watch the trailer, and see Pooh, then it's obvious what this is going to be. It's a throwback to campy horror. Over-the-top gore. Unstoppable slasher terrifying young women vacationing in the woods. Meat hooks and rednecks.

This is Jason X in 100 Acre Woods. It's Blood Diner in rubber masks. Not since Garbage Paul Kids have we seen so much of a slobbery gross good time.

If you get that concept, and appreciate that concept, then you will likely laugh as much as I did.

I love gore that doesn't look realistic. And none of this gore is anywhere close to realistic.

If the budget of this movie were cut in half, I could totally see Uncle Lloyd distributing this via Troma... and that's not a bad thing.

It's stupid.

It's meant to be stupid.

It's proud to be stupid.

It's just a stupid good time.

review_title: Good Idea, Not So Good Execution
review_detailed_main: I did like the idea behind it all but thought it was executed poorly. I mean, even for a budget film, there was almost little to no effort put into the design of Pooh & Piglet. We're expected to believe they are the actual charachters but they were clearly two guys wearing masks like any mask you could buy in a costume shop which is why there's practically no change of facial expressions in the two of them at all, apart from one scene & it only lasts about two seconds, probably a cost saving feature. So all & all, it was nothing particularlly special & I wouldn't be in a rush to watch it again.

Ls,

I went to this movie with my girlfriend and expected a Pooh slasher with a wink. It was worse, much worse.

Making a movie about a.homicidal and bloodthirsty Winnie the Pooh, could be so much more. They didnt even take the effort to make something nice out of it. Bad actors, bad acting, bad scenery, bad storyline (Ior didnt even had a role in the movie) the list is endless.

Rate is and absolute 1, its a missed chance of giving Pooh and Piglet a new life.

I heard that the license for Mickey Mouse also expires soon. Hopefully they make something better out of that one.

Have a good one.

Tjeerd.

review_title: It's hard to get worse than this!
review_detailed_main:
From all the other comments, as well as from my rating (I would give it a zero if possible), it's clear what kind of movie this is. But even though this is just a mere waste of time, I want to say that I enjoyed the depictions of the grotesqueness of our beloved characters from stories/cartoons. A humanoid, yellow, smiling teddy bear that talks - is there anything more horrifying than that? Not to mention all the other creatures from the "happy children's world," I simply couldn't decide who would suit a bloody chainsaw better.

PS: It would have been nice if the costume designer had a budget larger than a hundred euros.

What a load of rubbish. I've Never been so disappointed in a film in years and I've been disappointed a lot.

Every option the film makers had in writing this script, they chose the wrong one. I have so many questions but no answers. I feel like there was a pot luck with different plots and this is what came out.

There was genuinely likable characters who were there for 30 seconds before getting killed but they kept the most annoying ones and what's the story with Christopher Robin being such a wimp? Man up Christopher Robin.

Also where the hell is Rabbit?

I think this entire film is just a money grab to fund the sequel which will obviously be there to fund the third film.

I could write a better script in an hour and make this a great movie. ZERO STARS!! If I could give a zero I would have.

They came up with the idea of taking a beloved character and making him bad. I was looking forward to a good horror slasher flick with a twist but instead what I got a was just a hot mess. Watch it in the background while you are doing something else. Thats my recommendation. The idea is you can turn off your brain and watch this, so you can multitask. Poorly written script, a lot of it was quite predictable from the get-go. The acting was mediocre, and Christopher Robin was exceptionally bad. The movie ended is the dumbest way possible. Perhaps than ran out of ideas on how to wrap the movie up and so I guess the ending was actually real. Maybe they told good ol Chris that they broke their budget, he wasn't getting paid and thus his sudden change and the change in the ending.

review_title: If I could give it 0 stars I would.
review_detailed_main:
This had an interesting premise (by the title).

I should have followed the reviews (3.5 as of 25/3/23).

After the first two minutes it went downhill (fast).

It was an awful movie - acting, special effects, story line, talking (by the female actors). Nothing could have saved this movie to make it become viewable.

As another reviewer said, sometimes the masks that the protaganists use ride up, revealing human skin below.

I honestly urge you to give this movie (and I use the word loosely) a wide berth and watch something that's at least viewable (I'm watching "The Night Guard" at the moment - it's a bit long but must more viewable than this drivel).

Reviews from folks are taking this movie way too serious. This is a horror movie that is already halfway sold in the trailer. Either you want to see it or you. Just be rational and quit taking a silly little movie serious. This is one bloody good time and bloody for sure.

The Winnie the Pooh story is what everyone has grown up on. What would happen if Christopher Robbin grew up? Went to college and moved away? Life would go on but there's no one to take care of his animals and they resort to their instincts in the wild to live. Including eating, well not gonna give that away but it sets off a series of bloody events.

When adult Christopher does come back those cuddly forest creatures are out for blood. They wipe out everyone in their path. There's a brief moment where Christopher Robin is able to get through to Pooh. Then the slaughter continues. The ending was a little rough and kinda sad. No spoilers but the franchise window was left open. So sit back and enjoy this little gore.

review_title: Definitely not an Oscar winner, but a fun and crazy horror movie nonetheless
review_detailed_main:
I'll admit. When this movie was revealed, I was 100% against it. A Winnie the Pooh horror movie? The concept was blasphemous. But overtime, I slowly started to open up to the idea. I still wasn't sure I was going to see it, but I ended up caving.

Granted, the movie definitely isn't perfect. But it has some great kills, a good bit of suspense, and some admittedly great performances by the actors playing Pooh and Piglet. And honestly, it distanced itself from the Disney version of the characters and the tone of the books enough that my childhood really isn't ruined by this movie.

All in all, for an independent horror movie made on such a small budget of less than $100,000 it's pretty good. It has the energy of a grindhouse midnight movie.

review_title: They Did not Try Hard Enough
review_detailed_main: Well, Winnie the Pooh:Blood and Honey could have been something special, but instead it was a cheap C movie with unattractive actors, cheap masks, and Texas Chainsaw,dime-a-dozen script and zero redeeming value. What is the point if all a movie does is plagiarize as many horrible slasher movies as it can? There was NOTHING remotely cute, intelligent, engrossing, or different about this movie when it could have been so good. We could have had cute Winnie the Pooh characters with even CGI, and we could have seen the psychological developments as they progressed, and we could have had an emotional stake in this movie.

Lord have mercy on the souls that brought us here. This was just awful. Any rating over a three is either fake or the person voted for Biden. ( that would make you an idiot ) Now to be honest I hate UK movies. I love the accents but I just think they make crappy movies. Now Hott Fuzz was excellent. Anyway let's get back to this review. Sorry edible is kicking in. Just the movie being so dark all the time made this just unwatchable. Nothing is worse than a movie where it's so dark. Turn up the brightness for God Sakes. My 12 year old son said its not even scary, cause you can't see anything. I imagine it's dark cause you would see how crappy the pig and Winnie look. Oh well lesson learned.

I really had to review it, like WOW!! This is the worst movie I had ever seen in my life! This movie is just a disgrace to the original Disney's Winnie the Pooh, it also ruined my childhood!

Let me explain why it is bad.. The acting is just a bit off the target, the CGI effects are stupid, and the worst part is that the killing scenes are just bad!!

If you dare watch this movie, please don't watch it because it might ruin your childhood. Plus, I would rather watch Disney's original Winnie the Pooh better than this piece of junk.. I will rate this a one star. Also, not to mention that the director who made this was Rhys Frake-Waterfield.

review_title: This is Probably Another Level of Stupidity
review_detailed_main:

Not not mention that the costumes are just stupid and childish, and the masks won't even scare you. Also, screaming the names "Poo" and "Piglet" is not really a good idea for a horror or a slasher movie. And why the hell is Poo crying honey?? What is going on??

The acting is hideous and the production is probably done with an iPhone app. I wish I never heard of this. Such a horrible experience. Please stop making cheap movies. It's an insult to the film industry.

review_title: Disney, you can now sue the director for making this movie.
review_detailed_main: This is one of the worst things of 2023 along with the Velma series from HBO Max. I am very happy that this movie didn't release in theaters in my area and IT DOESN'T DESERVE TO AT ALL. This really hurts all of the people who grew up on the Disney versions of Winnie The Pooh. Some Disney franchises don't even deserve horror movies to begin. Thank god this movie is getting bad reviews and nominated for multiple raspberry awards for worst picture. So I went to watch blood and honey and I went in knowing how this movie wouldn't be good, I knew who would be directing it and, after looking up their past projects, I had an image on how this movie would be, and it had to be one of the most fun movies to watch I have ever seen in a theater. review_title: I could have made a better movie on this budget.
review_detailed_main: This movie is horrible. The killers wore masks. They are supposed to be actual creatures from fairy tale. But you can see the masks are rubber, there's even a time you see the actors heads under the masks. Characters are unbelievably idiotic, like when one character goes to get gas and the gas station is obviously abandoned. They could have done better. It was like they didn't even try with this film. They threw it together and edited it poorly. I have made better videos on Tik Tok than this abomination. I have seen better videos with HALF this budget! HALF! If you're going to use creatures, you can't have a rubber mask with the same goofy expression the entire time. This movie would have been a bit better if they went the route of the killers hiding their true identities under masks, and had a main protagonist. But that's not the road they took. They had the tools to make a great low budget film, and vomited all over it. Give me 100K and I could assure you I would have made MUCH better.

I think I have not seen move this bad ever. I was going into this movie, knowing it will be a disaster, but wow, it really surpassed my expectations.

First of all, every scene has taken so long that if was not for my friend, who I watched it together with, I would just walk away from this. This 84 minutes movie would literally take about 15 minutes if each scene was not unnecessarily stretched for extra one or two minutes. Sometimes you are just looking at character walking or doing nothing for the whole time!

The jumpscares were so predictable but not only a few but all of them, from start to beginning, every scare was made the same way. The story was boring, without point, sometimes illogical. Characters were either stupid or slow.

Only good thing was happening outside the movie. Talking about how bad every part of the movie is and having laugh at it.

review_title: Even low expectations are too much...
review_detailed_main:
Well, I already didn't go into this movie expecting much, so I can't really say I was "disappointed". However, I can 100%, confidently state that this was a bad movie. And by bad, I mean that there was not a single aspect of this movie I can actively classify as good. You may have heard there is no "wrong way" to approach a passion project (if that is in fact what this movie was to the film crew; perhaps I'm being generous here), but if there ever WAS a wrong way, well this movie just nailed it. The plot is actually so much of a disservice to itself, that the only consistent thing about this movie was how consistently awful it was. All 100 minutes of it. (About 95 minutes too long, if you ask me). Every bit of dialogue and exposition and "tension-building" goes on far longer than it needs to, so much so that I ended up spacing out mid-way through just about EVERY scene. But here's the kicker; it's absolutely not possible to miss any meaningful information to the plot. This is because... there is absolutely no. Meaningful. Information. In the plot. There is no continuity in the plot. Don't even get me started on the sheer lack of character in this movie. Don't get me wrong, this movie HAS characters, but they are so meaningless and one-dimensional that it feels like they've casted actors as props rather than people. If you're looking for character development, a story you can actually follow, and a movie that is more worth your time than doing literally anything else, maybe look somewhere else. Or, grab a few friends, and maybe the commentary amongst yourselves will provide the content this movie so desperately yearned to have. You will not gain anything by watching this movie except maybe an understanding of just how difficult it is to articulate exactly how meaningless every bit of this movie is.

Tl;dr: A movie that is so mediocre, that it's not even remarkably bad; it's just markably not good. If you're going in with low expectations, just drop them altogether. This movie warrants no expectations.

I feel that this movie's casting call was for the ugliest people that the director could scrape out of the bottom of the barrel. Not to mention how utterly and mind numbingly stupid this sad excuse for a movie is, the writers were not determined to make an honest horror film. But, instead they wanted to make a movie the was solely based on shock value rather than put their efforts in to writing a good script. It's easy to shoulder a movie on shock value alone, however, it takes talent to make a horror movie that is worth watching. No matter how hard I try, I just can't comprehend how a movie this ridiculous received any kind of funding, and it doesn't seem like this movie got any. The costumes are so bad they are laughable, and the actors are cringey throughout, the worst of them being Natasha Tosini. I am assuming she was to be the resident, "worldly" character who you know the killers are going to take out first. My problem with Natasha is that she is about the farthest thing from being attractive, and having to see her in a skimpy bikini was the most horrific thing in this, "slasher" movie. Yikes!

I was really looking forward to this one. Growing up with Winnie the pooh and a horror fan, I was super excited to see what they would do with this. Obviously I was preparing myself for a movie that wasn't too serious of a horror film, but I can definitely say that this.. wasn't my expectation at all.

First off let me say that the acting was horrible. I couldn't get myself to connect with any of them and I can most definitely say that even my cats can act out even more! But unfortunately this isn't the worst of the movie.. the budget isn't too high so I do understand that we cannot expect the most amazing details and grime make-up and sfx but still.. The camera work was worse than I could've imagined and this was one of the many reasons that I turned the movie of at about 30 minutes. I never experienced anything like this before but I couldn't finish this movie. If it was still enjoyable , like a lot of movies were to me even with a small budget, then I'll watch them all till the end. This one just wasn't it unfortunately... if I could give you a tip... if you want to save yourself some time.. skip this one.

I wish I'd have read the reviews before wasting my time on this dumpster fire. I wasn't really expecting it to be good to begin with, but I tried to go into it with an open mind and give it a fair shake. I thought I'd at least get a few laughs out of it. Wrong. I found myself angry, bordering on physically ill over how poorly this movie (I use that term loosely) was executed. It ruined what could have been a cool adaptation of the classic children's character by taking itself way too seriously, and it may have ruined movies in general for me. From the script, to the costume and set design, to the cinematography; everything was abysmal. The plot holes were abundant and the character development was non-existent. Literally every character was stupid and unlikable, and I found myself actively rooting against every single one of them. How someone already green-lit a sequel is beyond me but at least I'll know better than to waste my time on that one. Fool me once...

When I first heard that there was going to be a winnie the pooh slasher film I laughed and thought "really, are they actually going to make something this daft" then the Internet went awash with crazy theories about what it would be like until finally we got a trailer and it looked ridiculous! And you know what it is, but its so ridiculous it works. Its not going to win any awards and it's a complete b movie slash fest but that's all I wanted, to see Winnie the pooh stomping around killing people and I got it.

Forget the negativity if you want a daft film about a childhood hero that turns out to be a wrong un them give it a watch. The kills are funny, the characters are cliché and it left me with a smile on my face!

review_title: The film was ok but just a couple of negatives
More like Winnie The Pooh trashy and forgettable
review_detailed_main: This movie is nothing but a disgrace to the Winnie The Pooh franchise they only did this for money this movie is so awful that makes The Mean One look like a good movie in comparison, the plot for this movie is about Pooh getting revenge on Christopher Robin after he goes to university and the new design of Winnie The Pooh is horrible and if this movie got a sequel i am not looking forward to see it because it will be a waste of time and i also find this to be one of the worst films from 2023 next to House Party and Life Upside Down, thank god i never watched it and i would rather watch The Many Adventures Of Winnie The Pooh and the 2011 version rather than this piece of garbage.

review_title: All of those character are " Stupid "

review_detailed_main:

The trailers make it look like it might actually be worth a watch. Get yourself all settled for the night, lights off, curtains closed then you're ready....here we go...I've been waiting for this it's gonna be gooooooood! review_title: I saw the poor rating and figured it can't be that bad

Just wow. Don't waste your time on this.....

review_title: I hate this movie, but I love the 2nd one
A Breathtaking Masterpiece: Winnie the Pooh in Blood and Honey Shines Bright with 10 Stars!
review_detailed_main:
Prepare to be enchanted, captivated, and moved beyond words as you embark on a stunning cinematic journey with "Winnie the Pooh in Blood and Honey." This extraordinary adaptation takes the beloved characters we know and love from the Hundred Acre Wood and delves into a realm of deep introspection, raw emotions, and profound storytelling. It is a true work of art that deserves every bit of its perfect 10-star rating.

Director Christopher Talbot has accomplished something truly remarkable by infusing the whimsical world of Winnie the Pooh with an unexpected, yet thought-provoking blend of realism and symbolism. From the very first frame, the audience is transported into a visually mesmerizing and emotionally charged experience that leaves an indelible mark on the soul.

The performances in this film are nothing short of extraordinary. Each actor fully immerses themselves in their respective roles, breathing new life into these iconic characters. Ewan McGregor's portrayal of a tormented and emotionally complex Pooh Bear is nothing short of revelatory. His nuanced performance evokes a deep sense of empathy and invites the audience to explore the depths of their own emotions.

The screenplay, penned by the talented Elizabeth Rodriguez, weaves a tale that effortlessly combines the sweetness and innocence of the original stories with a darker, more mature narrative. It explores themes of love, loss, friendship, and the complexities of the human experience. Rodriguez's writing is poetic and profound, capturing the essence of A. A. Milne's original vision while adding layers of depth and emotional resonance.

The cinematography in "Winnie the Pooh in Blood and Honey" is simply breathtaking. Each frame is meticulously crafted, creating a visually stunning feast for the eyes. The use of color, light, and shadow is masterful, enhancing the emotional impact of every scene. The attention to detail is awe-inspiring, from the beautifully animated honey jars to the enchanting landscapes of the Hundred Acre Wood.

The musical score, composed by Alexandre Desplat, is a true masterpiece. It perfectly complements the visuals and performances, elevating the film to new heights of emotional intensity. The melodies are both haunting and uplifting, leaving a lasting impression on the viewer's heart.

In addition to its artistic merits, "Winnie the Pooh in Blood and Honey" is also a triumph in terms of its cultural significance. It challenges societal expectations and preconceived notions, reminding us that even the most beloved children's stories can hold deeper meanings and resonate with audiences of all ages.

To say that "Winnie the Pooh in Blood and Honey" is a cinematic gem would be an understatement. It is a transformative experience that touches the soul and ignites the imagination. This film is a testament to the power of storytelling and its ability to transcend boundaries. It is an absolute must-see for anyone seeking a profound and unforgettable cinematic experience.

With its exceptional performances, brilliant screenplay, breathtaking cinematography, and mesmerizing score, "Winnie the Pooh in Blood and Honey" earns a well-deserved 10-star rating. Prepare to be moved, enlightened, and forever changed by this extraordinary cinematic masterpiece.

review_title: Not good but better than expected
review_detailed_main:
Okay, first you have to remember it was made for $100k - you don't judge it for not being a $1M film. That's why the review is 7.5 stars (rounded down) instead of 4.5. If a regular studio released this, it would deserve all the quality complaints it got.. but it's not from those so it shouldn't be treated as if it is.

Also - for people missing characters. Only things in the 1928 book are allowed. So no modern-Tigger or some other pieces that either Disney invented or were in later writings.

It has problems. The dialog is choppy throughout. The acting is a mix of some good, some not good and some...poor (even for the price - the 4 guys are embarrassing in acting and dialog). There are complicated deaths that make little sense and 1 add-on victim that makes even less sense.

The writer/director should have gotten someone else to edit besides himself (per the credits). That might have helped.

That said, the story is a good one. The framing idea was well done, the story with the girls is well put together and held together for a horror film. A couple of small bits made no sense but it screamed edited-out scene more than anything else. Some of the issues are easily fixed through an editor / script doctor.

The use of atmosphere (visual and audio) was well done (some great use of music). When the subtle music shift makes the hairs on the arm stand up, you've done your job.

Deaths were hit and miss - some typical nonsense "movie complicated' but 2 were perfectly done (3rd to last and last). You expect that today, regardless of who releases it (SAW's deaths are also the same).

Overall, I'd recommend it to those who like horror and don't care if it is low budget. Those needing SCREAM production-quality should avoid.

When I heard there would be a Winnie the Pooh slasher I was excited and intrigued.

This film serves merely as a concept film. I know it's an indie flick and obviously budget is low, production values are low, acting is terrible and all that, but the movie itself serves as little more that a story boarding exercise.

Perhaps the producers are hoping a better funded and more competent firm will take their idea and make a better movie.

I'm finding it hard to think of any redeeming features aside from the opening scene, which is animated and sets the scene for what should be a dark and interesting movie.

It is neither of those things even if it tries to be.

A lot of horror movies are guiltily of being little more than a succession of gory kills of unlikeable characters you never related to and don't care about.

This movie is that dialled to 11.

I can overlook bad lightning and a low budget and even poor writing but I can't stand a movie with bad acting and *everyone* is terrible. They're all so bad it makes me wonder if they deliberately found terrible actors on purpose for some bizarre reason because I can't fathom them all being this bad on accident.

It's such a shame everyone is so bad at acting because, poor writing aside, it would have been impressive they filmed it in 10 days.

I hope someone else makes a Winnie the Pooh horror movie because it's a cool concept but do not waste your time with this movie. The bad acting is just too painful and embarrassing to sit through.

review_title: how bad can you go with no budget?
review_detailed_main:
Well, you can expect total BS movie with such title, but it can still surprise you how bad it can be. As always I won't spoil anything but give some feedback of the technical aspect of the movie. But you can't expect much from such movie esp when they have micro-budget.

So, acting 0. These actors/actresses have very little or no experience at all, looks more like bunch of friends deciding to make fan movie. Maybe tad better because of the main character. Similar to Troma movies basically. Script and dialogues are also 0/10. That is no surprise considering the topic but some scenes don't even make sense. Not to mention all the clichés that are so typical for most horror movies.

Camera work is very bad almost trough the entire movie. But here i will say the only 2 positive things. First - some of the shots were actually great. While they didn't have that much money, there are cool shots with fog in the forest and dust light beans in the wood shed that look awesome in horror movies in general. The 2nd good thing about this is the editing at times. It has kinda mid 2000s vibe. It's not constant but i'm giving them that.

No info of the gear used for it, but from what i see, it's just entry level DSLR/mirrorless camera with kit lens if i do an educated guess from the background and how it changes in different scenes. Totaly amateurish setup, they didn't even bother paying few bucks to rent a better lenses, it's quite cheap to rent.

These masks look as cheap AF. As they went to the 1-dollar-store and bought the cheapest one available there. The blood and gore look bad too, tho you can't expect more from such a budget. Overal the VFX are bad.

And who'd choosen the music... songs like "bad smell" lol ... Overal, terrible movie. It has the cheap quality of Troma movies, but they are at least funny sometimes :D This is not.

review_title: An Abysmal Slap In The Face (And A Middle Finger) To The Beloved A. A. Milne Classic

review_detailed_main: Okay, this is by far the worst horror movie I have ever seen. For instance, the script was so bad I could do a better Script in one week. Even the acting was terrible. It's feels like a self-made movie of some hobby actors who has no experience. The idea was not that bad to put Winnie poo into a horror movie, because Winnie Pooh is friendly and a nice character and we all know him since back in the days. The one thing I liked is how the characters died because it was brutal, which fits into the movie. Nevertheless, the story of horror movies are not so difficult to generate, so I'm just wondering how this is possible to mess that up. No more to say!

review_title: Predictably atrocious butchery of a beloved literary icon
review_detailed_main:
STAR RATING: ***** Brilliant **** Very Good *** Okay ** Poor * Awful

Years ago, young Christopher Robin discovered Winnie the Pooh and his friends while playing out in the woods, and developed some wonderful childhood memories. But then, he had to go off to college and left his animal friends on their own, forcing them to fend for themselves, and leaving them to resort to a savage act. Years later, Christopher Robin returns to the woods with his partner, only for Pooh and his friends to exact a terrible revenge, whilst a group of female friends take a vacation that will end in blood.

Last year, the copyright on A. A. Milne's classic literary creation, Winnie the Pooh expired, leaving anyone who was interested free to cast their own creative interpretation of the story without any fear of getting sued by the almighty Disney. So, the filmmakers behind this unimaginable nonsense decided, what would anyone like to see better than a psychopathic Winnie the Pooh and his mates going wild on their old pal Chris Robin, and a group of standard shrieking, slow witted brunettes typical of any slasher film? Nothing. So, with the most seemingly minuscule of budgets and with what must surely be a cast of none professional actors, they followed their dreams. And this...is the result.

It feels a little disingenuous to give a really bad review to something that, at the very least, you knew was never going to be an Oscar winner. But, sometimes the slowing-down-at-a-car-crash effect can set in, and you just want to gawp at something just to see how bad it is, and I allowed myself to fall prey to this phenomenon here (as I had nothing better to watch.) The awful acting and dismal production values could be overlooked if the whole thing seemed to have a genuine sense of its own preposterousness, and kept its tongue firmly in its cheek, but with a silent Pooh and his friends unable to deliver any Krueger style wisecracks, it's just left to linger in its own bleak nihilism, until an abrupt end filling in where the budget must have run out.

The novelty behind the film (a psychotic Winnie the Pooh!) gave the film some publicity that allowed it the slightly elevated status of a limited theatre release, but fundamentally it has no merit above all the other low budget horror trash that creeps out direct to DVD every month. *

review_title: A highly enjoyable effort in the right mindset
review_detailed_main:
Trying to come to terms with her past, a woman and her girlfriends rent a house in the remote countryside to help her, but when they find their trip crashed by vicious animalistic serial killers on a bloodthirsty rampage must rely on their wits and a former friend of the creatures to stop them.

This was a highly effective and enjoyable cheesy genre effort. Among the better features here is the earnestness with which the film takes the wild and silly storyline. Setup from the start to take full advantage of the popularity of the characters with the way it wraps the traditional stories into something different, the newfound direction it takes by providing the proper reasoning for their rampant bloodthirsty nature by utilizing the abandonment of their past is handled well. This has enough to bridge the past connections into being reasonable killers due to the perceived anger and betrayal that takes place here provides a lot to like as a setup. That provides this one with the perfect opportunity to unleash some genuinely more effective scares than expected. Taking full advantage of the effectively eerie wilderness of the woods where it all takes place, the early scenes of the couple getting stalked in the hideout they used to live in or the stranded victim outside the factory where they operate out of, giving this some quite chilling scenes. A later scene of a victim in a hot tub unaware of the approaching killers who are obscured in blinking lights or the group being confronted with the aftermath of their handiwork completes this nicely enough as there are some creepy sequences at play in this one. As well, there's a lot of brutality at stake here once the creatures make their presence known to the girls. The overwhelming nature of their home invasion takeover brings some great scenes here chasing them around with their superior size or beating them to death using their weaponry leads perfectly into the great finale. Taking place at the creatures' hideout where the brutality of their beatings inflicted on others they've captured which lets the film include plenty of high-end chases, confrontations, and a thoroughly frantic final half that's incredibly over-the-top and graphic deaths which is all sorts of fun. Altogether, these are enough to make for a rather fun time here as this one doesn't have much but there are some slight issues. One of the few drawbacks present here is the viewers' own personal preference for the treatment of the characters. Rather than do anything remotely familiar with the usual treatment of the characters, this one features them as vicious, brutal serial killers out to decimate anyone and everyone they come across which can be outright insulting depending on your individual attachment to the characters. If that's not a factor, the cheap nature of what's happening and the intensely shaking camera on display when we see the creatures moving after others that's difficult to make out are the main issues to bring it down.

Rated Unrated/R: Extreme Graphic Violence, Graphic Language, and Nudity.

review_title: A mess from start to finish
review_detailed_main:
'Winnie-the-Pooh: Blood and Honey' is the definition of a film that sounds a lot more fun in theory than it actually turned out to be. The actual product was an absolute slog to get through. To be fair, it's a little hard to judge the concept because the film was executed very poorly.

I haven't seen wafer-thin characters like this in a long time. Absolutely nothing went into developing them in the script. Also the monsters weren't developed either. We get some half-hearted narration at the beginning that tries to justify their actions and that's it. They can't talk so we never get any more development out of them.

I will say I was glad the run time was short. With that said, the ending was bizarre and was no kind of ending at all. This was just a mess from start to finish. 3/10.

I don't do many reviews unless it's necessary and believe me this is necessary. I'm a huge fan of horror and watch alot of low budget b movies , so I know what to expect. I was very excited when I heard that they were making a horror of winnie the poo and really looking forward to this. And thinking finally Disney was going to the dark side because it was about time. But I was sadly very disappointed. The acting was diabolical, stupid and laughable. And the dialogue was just really really poorly written and so bad. By half way through the film I couldn't wait for it to end but looking at run time i realised I still had another hour to get through. The reason I'm only giving a 3 is because of the death kills otherwise I wouldn't even give it a score.

As a fan of horror in all forms.. I always try to give each movie a fair go, 90 percent of the time these movies are strictly one off watch and forget and 8 percent are great and rewatchable... that 2 percent? That's for that rare turd which you can't get back that time you spent watching it and it's forever burnt into your memory... this Movie.. lack of a better term is the reason why IMBD needs to create a zero or negative rating system. Let's start with yes, it's a low budget movie.. but seriously there was no effort to hide that low budget here.. on display is some of the worst-case bottom of the barrel acting, script, gore effects and direction and sadly there is nothing here to recommend.

This movie was wack straight up. I gave me a vibe of hills have eyes with mask on. The acting was crap and you can tell these actors are fresh out of acting school. The plot made no sense. Who ever put this together needs to be taking out back and shot! Burrrn the whole script and don't even start over just leave it alone. It's been plenty of times the victims could of made their get away but the crappy acting made it look so fake. I would only recommend this movie if someone wanted to have a good laugh. What happened to the other characters as well... Tiger, Owl, Rabbit, Roo. This was just an all around stupid movie.

If I could put 0 stars I would. The acting is POOR. The plot holes are HUGE. It's just animals torturing people. The movie's budget is obviously low and I don't understand why there's a sequel. The movie's aim is to only shock the viewer and nothing else. The movie is very gory without any reason and the main characters choices are very questionable. My childhood is ruined. Winnie-the-Pooh and the other animals are looking like people with a mask on their faces. Not to mention that the animals are traumatized and doing all that horrible things they do to other people because a kid they used to play with had to leave them to go to college. They are just SELFISH . DO NOT WATCH THIS MOVIE IF YOU DONT WANT TO DIE FRON CRINGE!!

review_title: So bad you have watch it to believe it.
review_detailed_main: If you're expecting to see a giant, adult, Pooh Bear complete with giant paws and claws, that looks great through modern visual and special effects, then prepare to disappointed. It's just a bloke in hiking boots and dungarees wearing a rubber mask. I wanted to see a huge bear snarling with giant teeth dropping with blood, but our Pooh has no facial expressions and don't believe he even blinks. The acting is laughable and don't expect to see any of these actors names on the Hollywood walk a game anytime soon. There's zero suspense, shock, or scares. It's just cheap gore you have seen a thousand times in similar low budget slasher movies. IMDB has the estimated budget at $100k and i think that says it all. They have used Pooh's name to make a quick buck and have put in a minuscule amount of time, effort and expense into the project. Shameful.

I shouldn't bother with a review, because the rest of them are right about everything. This movie is just bad. I was looking forward to having some laughs with this one, thinking it would be so bad that it would funny. But the writing is just awful. The acting is worse, especially from Christopher Robin. And there was no ending! It just randomly ended. This could have been made so much better, as one of those humorous slashers. But someone wanted to make this film so badly even though they had no actual ideas, so they made it anyway. The first hour of this movie is so painful that I put it in 2x speed to get it over with faster. In the last 30 minutes, I finally did get a couple laughs, like when Pooh seriously did the Vulcan death pinch. Really?

review_title: A great B-movie that is better then what most people are saying.
So bad, I'm at a loss for words.
review_detailed_main: I came into this movie knowing it wasn't going to be The Exorcist, Halloween or even Sleep away Camp. But I thought it would at least be watchable and that I would get a laugh or two, I was sadly mistaken. This movie is horrible. I've seen better things in my cats litter box. Avoid this movie at all costs. I can't believe they made a sequel. Of course I'm going to watch it, I already hate myself for willing to go through it again. The acting is horrible,it's British if anyone cares. The movies "special" effects probably costed around a $1.50, or the equivalent ien British pounds. I usually don't write reviews but this movie is so bad that I had too.

review_title: A strange idea that has not yet been discovered
review_detailed_main:
The best thing about the movie is the photography in certain scenes and some gore scenes among many other bad ones... It's entertaining if it plays in the background while you do other things.

He has many problems. From weird cuts in scenes, absurd dialogues or poorly designed gore scenes and results.

Although the idea was strange, it had some potential and has been largely wasted by the poor characterization of the enemies, who more than mutant creatures look like psychopaths with disguised masks... It would have been smarter to have made a slasher with this theme of disguised psychopaths Winnie the Poo theme...

review_title: Should've ended after the title sequence...
review_detailed_main:
Watching the first ten minutes of the film, I was blown away. Was it great, no, but there was an interesting spin on the classic story everyone is familiar with. The drawn imagery, as if out of a storybook, is creepy but fits the theme. The turn of events that leads to Pooh and his friends becoming evil isn't the most believable but is better than many horror movies. Christopher returning to 100-acre woods is creepy and the result, while expected, has the freight you'd expect from a slasher. The problem is one many monster horror films struggle with. The second that Pooh and Piglet are revealed, they stop being as scary, for it is the anticipation of them that makes them most terrifying. The novelty of these characters also quickly fades when you realize that the Winne-the-Pooh theme has little bearing on any aspect of the film outside of the first few minutes. It ends up becoming a mediocre slasher that offers close to nothing.

The funny thing about this film is I think if they left it as a 10-minute short film, just including the part that comes before the title sequence, it would've been excellent. It was involved in the lore of Winnie-the-Pooh, creepy, but believable enough in the universe. Instead, they drew it out (likely to make more money) and ended up with something unmemorable and overdone.

Far as horror & it's sub-genres, most realize that big budget horror films are a rarity & that's ok. Maybe a handful every yr are backed with ample budgets, but most films going back to golden age in Hollywood have been lower budget films. With saying that, there have still been ton of great movies made in genre. But its important to have realistic expectations. If watching a slasher, it's rather silly to expect some epic romanticized screen play acted out let alone get Oscar worthy performances. Idk what some peeps expect sometimes looking at reviews. This had major potential imo yet fell way short. Lighting made it hard to watch & I'm guessing budget really hindered what they could do. Some can do more with less, than others.

This film boasts a fun premise that definitely delivers. It's a microbudget production, but easily provides a great time despite that. The music is well timed and adds a layer to the movie that takes it to the next level. See your favorite childhood characters in a new way. Just temper your expectations appropriately. With a title like: Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey, I think we all have a good idea of what we are getting into here. Support for smaller films like this is what changes lives and careers, and that is something everyone can get behind. Go see it when it comes to a theater near you.

review_title: Sequel is the one to watch!
review_detailed_main: This first film seems to be the low budget piece that it is, but it has certainly spiked so much interest with the twist on the childhood story. The second film has a great cast and bigger budget and I think is the one to watch! The guys had so much more to play with and the photographs look like a whole different quality.. the filmmaking I think will be a better calibre on this first attempt. The press features certainly promise something special! I'm looking forward to seeing if the film lives up to the hype and is much more impressive than the first. Comes out in February and I can't wait to give it a watch.

After watching the first half of "Blood and Honey," I was initially inclined to defend this movie after reading both critic and user reviews. However, my optimism diminished after I watched the second half.

First and foremost, what did people expect from "Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey"? If you walked in with the expectation that it would become an instant cult classic and redefine the horror genre, then you approached it with the wrong mindset. "Blood and Honey" was always destined to be a low-budget B-grade horror film at its finest. And for the first third of the film, it exceeded those expectations. You witness graphic kills, nudity, and two hulking brutes that resemble serial killers in poorly fitted leathery masks more than mutated creatures from the Hundred Acre Wood.

I considered the possibility that some reviews might have succumbed to the #metoo movement concerning a group of girls being slaughtered, or perhaps the criticism of the movie's lack of diversity. I dreaded the less-than-insightful commentary that critics often provide nowadays, where even films like 'Deadpool' are hailed as good.

"Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey" is not nearly as terrible as some make it out to be. It's too simplistic to label it a mere 'cash grab'. The writers and director clearly leveraged a well-known children's classic to draw people to the film, and the publicity and marketing alone achieved that goal, regardless of how poorly the film ultimately turned out.

This falls right in line with "Charlie's Farm": limited backstory, cheesy dialogue, innovative ways to portray violence on screen, a weak ending, and painstakingly cringe-worthy CGI. Nevertheless, this film is watchable.

The image of a tire from a vehicle pressing down on the girl's head was a gruesome triumph. I've had nightmares about a scenario like this playing out in real life, and now, even with some questionable late 1990s to early 2000s CGI, I can confidently say it wouldn't be a pleasant outcome.

The highlights are the early storyboards depicting the backstory of Pooh and his friends. The drawings hint at deeper layers of sadness and complexity to our beloved characters. I only wish they had delved further down this path because it was truly fascinating, and I wanted to know more.

The low points include certain scenes that made it into the final cut, such as the one where our main heroine stands at the top of the staircase, gun in hand, with ample opportunities to shoot Pooh and end the nightmare before her best friend loses her head right in front of her eyes.

Another perplexing scene is the one at the indoor pool. While one of the girls falls into the water, frightened by Piglet, and screams at him to leave her friend alone, she seems to do everything but try to run and escape. Somehow, a hulking Piglet, wielding a sledgehammer and chain, jumps into the pool, wades through the water at a pace slower than Andre the Giant, but catcher her nevertheless and nearly decapitates her with a mighty swing.

Lastly, what's with their intelligent yet brutal methods of killing? I thought going animalistic meant they kill and eat people for sustenance, not pressing a foot on a girl's back to prevent her from escaping while another drives a car over her head... massive 'facepalm'. Unfortunately, this film is rife with such moments that defy reasoning.

I won't spend too much time discussing the acting. Nickolai Leon was serviceable, but apart from that, it's a rather sombre affair.

All in all, this doesn't come close to some of the trashy horror I've seen over the years. (I'm talking about you Unfriended and Invoked) However, it takes a freefalling nosedive by the end, and the more you contemplate the plot's meaning, the more absurd the entire film sounds.

3/10.

Oh dear Pooh... What happened to you and your (beloved) kid-friendly franchise...

At first, when the movie was announced, I was pretty surprised to see how a supposedly kid-friendly franchise like Pooh, being turned into something animalistis and sadistic like this? But again, I'm always a positive person and will always welcome a new idea.

So, when the trailer first hit the internet, I saw it and kinda liked the idea to a point where I was pretty excited to see the outcome. But upon watching it, I finally realized that I've wasted 86 minutes of my life for a movie that's badly produced.

Don't get me wrong, this movie actually has potential if executed properly. Gory and slasher movies still have great values, as long as it's executed nicely. Sadly, that's not the case with this one. Bad direction, bad lighting, bad script, bad story, bad acting, bad costume. Nothing good can be said about this one. Oh wait.. maybe one good thing is there: the killing and the gore.

Things I really hated about the movie is mainly on the following:

1. Actors and actresses who was pretty bland on the acting... 2. Terrible and inconsistent dialogue (10 minutes into the movie and I already felt like wanted to stop watching it because of the dialogue...) 3. Story which is under-developed 4. Bad costumes... (I mean, come on. In this era, where you can create a believable monster like Kingkong and Godzilla, but yet, the creatures just looked like over-juiced villain cosplaying as Pooh and Piglet, while going all Jason-esque style murder spree?)

I'm sorry, but I really don't recommend it, unless you really have lots of free time to spare and don't mind your childhood lovable-stories got butchered and turned upside down into full gore-style killing spree genre.

I still give it 3 stars out of 10, because I want to at least appreciate the idea, which again, is sadly, badly executed.

review_title: A Gut-Busting, Cheese-Filled Slaughter Through The Wood
review_detailed_main:
Hold onto your honey pots and prepare for a delectably cheesy, gore-filled adventure with "Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey," a horror-comedy extravaganza that reimagines our favorite childhood characters as deranged, bloodthirsty killers. This outrageously goofy cheese-fest offers a rollercoaster ride through the Hundred Acre Wood, leaving no stone (or entrail) unturned.

The plot is as absurd as it is entertaining: Christopher Robin abandons Pooh and Piglet, causing them to become feral, homicidal maniacs on a rampage of vengeance. Embracing its ridiculous premise with gusto, the film delivers buckets of blood, guts, and laugh-out-loud moments that will leave you in stitches (pun intended) a d saying WTF!

The kills are gloriously over-the-top and gratuitous, ensuring that horror fans with a taste for cheesy carnage will be satiated. Despite its low-budget charm, the practical effects and makeup are impressively grotesque, providing a visceral feast for the eyes.

The acting is as cheesy as it gets, but that's all part of the fun. Watching beloved childhood characters turned into murderous psychopaths is a guilty pleasure, and the cast fully commits to their roles with tongue-in-cheek humor.

Don't expect a deep, thought-provoking story, because "Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey" is all about the gore-soaked spectacle. It's a riotous, tongue-in-cheek celebration of slasher cinema, and it doesn't take itself seriously for a single moment.

I"Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey" is a gut-busting, cheese-filled slaughter through the Hundred Acre Wood that will have you laughing and cringing in equal measure. It's a perfect choice for horror fans who love their films extra bloody, extra cheesy, and extra outrageous. Just like an extra value meal topped up with extra cheese at your corner Burger King with an extra dose of gore-drenched fun.

review_title: I gave it a try! I really did.
No horror. Just violence, violence and violence
This is a $15,000 film that embraces what it is
review_detailed_main:
This was made with a budget of $15,000.

The acting isn't great.

The effects aren't great.

Looking at it through a critical lens, it's not great.

There are a lot of people looking through the lens of comparing it to large budget box offices hits. It will never measure up against those.

HOWEVER, the film knows this and embraces this in every way possible. It almost feels like thet are in on the joke.

If you are a fan of b-horror movie films that are so bad it's funny, this is for you. When you consider the truly tiny budget vs the budget of some terrible movies out there (that tried to be good), it's rather impressive what they accomplished.

review_title: You Know What you are Getting
review_detailed_main:
Is it the best movie? Of course it isn't. But I absolutely love how they jumped on this concept as soon as it was legally able to be made (minus the real likeness of characters as Disney still owns those rights). It is definitely a campy horror movie and if you go into it knowing it was made with a $100,000 budget and in 10 days. Congrats to everyone involved as it made over $5M.

Why did the horror happen? Because Christopher Robin said he would be with them forever and take care of them...That caused a lot of psychological issues with the Pooh, Piglet, Owl and Eeyore during a very harsh winter.

Enjoy it for what it is.

I watched this movie because there was a thread on Reddit that said people liked this as a cult classic good bad movie (see Birdemic or Troll 2) but it was just...meh. I went into it expecting the lackluster costumes (just a dude with a bear and pig mask and normal clothes) so that was fine. The lack of character development was fine. The premise of the story was fine, actually kind of interesting. My biggest issue (besides the obvious wtf moments...one of the characters having different pants on than when she was kidnapped, Pooh knowing how to drive) was that it just ended out of absolutely nowhere. Like, I was waiting for the big climax but then the end credits came on and I was like...what. Two minutes more and this would have gotten a better review. The only reason I gave it three stars instead of one is because I watched most of it ready to defend the numerous one star reviews because the movie itself before the ending isn't that terrible. And because I liked the beginning monologue where they explained the premise of the movie. So all in all the premise was cool, the execution terrible.

review_title: Not as good as i hoped
This is a movie that had the ingredients to be good but the budget to mess it up
review_detailed_main:
Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey(2023) is a movie that I watched tonight in theatres. The storyline follows life after Christopher Robin deserted Pooh, Piglet and friends. Pooh and and Piglet have had to resort to extreme methods for survival and resent Christopher Robin for their actions. As Christopher Robin feels guilty for deserting his friends he heads back to see if his memories are real. His actions may unleash hell on Earth.

This picture is directed by Rhys Frake-Waterfield (The Killing Tree AND the upcoming Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey 2 AND Peter Pan's Neverland Nightmare) and stars Gillian Broderick (Alive), Paula Coiz (Tooth Fairy Queen of Pain), Chris Cordell (Curse of Humpty Dumpty 2) and Craig David Dowsett (Area 51 Incident).

This film had so much potential - great settings, characters, soundtrack, use of lighting, soundtrack and background music. I really enjoyed the sets; unfortunately, the acting and dialogue was mediocre to really bad. The scenes were so inconsistently executed. The opening kills before the credits, torture scenes and hot tub scenes could have been so much better. The "I love you" and pool kill are absolutely awful. I will say the ladies are gorgeous and the topless red head kill was awesome...but we needed way more of that. The masks worked for me but I could see why people may complain about them. The bee CGI sequence wasn't good.

Overall, this is a movie that had the ingredients to be good but the budget to mess it up. I would score this a 4/10 but would still highly recommend it.

A horror movie based on the original version of Winnie the Pooh by AA Milne. I hate this horror movie AND this movie did disappoint me. It ruin my childhood. I was and is a big fan of Winnie the Pooh. I always see Winnie the Pooh a cute little bear, not turning a crazy monster. It is definitely not worth a watch for horror fans. It did let me down.

They made the most of the opportunity to turn a cute little bear and pig into 2 ugly crazy monsters on a killing rampage, however very not fun. I hate it.

So, not well done to everyone involved in the making of this movie.

Disney, please come in action for delete this movie. I really love Disney Winnie the Pooh.

review_title: Jason Vorhees In A Pooh Bear Mask
review_detailed_main: This movie was fun! Wait, did I say fun? I meant funny! While this was an interesting take on the Winnie The Pooh characters, it didn't execute itself very well. The story in itself was very predictable, stupid & rushed & the lack of half of the "Acres Woods" characters didn't make it a very good story. But on the upside, I did enjoy watching just because of how ridiculous it all was. From the story to the kills. I would recommend this for curiosity purposes only. This is okay for a one time watch, but something I would probably never sit through EVER again. The sequels should be interesting..

review_title: Neither the bloody slasher nor the campy send up you were hoping for
review_detailed_main:
Had it not been for the surge of media attention this movie got for using Winnie The Pooh as it's villain, it would have ended up buried in the bottom of the Amazon Prime horror offerings.

The film seems to lack the self aware humor or over the top gore that's the Terrifier movies cult classics, but somehow thinks it has both. The film drags for most of its run time, with backstory that leads nowhere, entire scenes that feel added to pad out the run time, and plodding chases full of all the excitement of apple sauce day that the nursing home. Most of the kills were PG-13 level violence, and the gorier offerings were executed with cartoon-ish CG that blunted any shock value the filmmakers might have hoped for.

This movie could have been great had the filmmakers just gone all out and made the craziest film they could. Instead it feels tediously restrained. And given the threadbare nature of the story and entirely unsatisfying non-resolution to the story, I can't help but think they thought the concept and kills alone would get them by.

I was really excited for this one, but left the theater seriously disappointed.

Never have I ever been so disgusted to see a film so despicable, especially when it comes to our favorite longtime favorite childhood characters be corrupted.

Whoever made this clearly had a bad childhood never had a good taste of beloved tv shows we grew up with.

Anyone who watches this, it will scar you for life.

Not bashing opinions, but if anyone likes this movie, will turn out to be like the main villain themselves.

I feel terrible for anyone who loves Winnie The Pooh have to process this, because I'm just as angry as everyone else is.

If the original actors were still alive today, they would be very disappointed.

I will NEVER recommend this movie to anyone.

review_title: Winnie-the-Pooh: Blood and Honey was the most disappointing thing since my son.
review_detailed_main: This movie had loads of potential. After the E. H. Sheppard inspired animation, and the reveal of evil Pooh and Piglet, I was hooked. But when the opening credits hit, it started to go downhill. The new characters were very underdeveloped, and even for horror movie standards, they made some poor decisions which led to them getting killed. The movie only sells on its premise, and does nothing with it. Even if it was also stupid, 'The Mean One' was at least enjoyable because that film knew it would suck, so it just went nuts. And even so, it was still better. It's sad to see a movie and following, a whole cinematic universe with loads of potential fall on its face, but that's life. We can hope Rhys Frake-Waterfield learns from this, and makes a better sequel, along with a Bambi and Peter Pan movie, but I have my doubts.

I surprised I liked this movie. I think 3 rating is too low. It should be a 5 at least by the audience. I rated it 8 meaning it was good but not rewatchable. 10 for me is good and rewatchable. 6 is ok and 4 is sucks. Pooh makes Jason and Michael look like pussies. It's like dealing with a predator except he's acts like the wrong turn hillbillies except in their own strange way. Pooh is not human obviously. A creature. The connection between Chris and Pooh seems like Chris can solve the situation but then is useless. It ended in a surprise and I can't wait for the next one to come. If I were to have to top 10 slasher franchises then this would be up there but it's a creature so is it a creature movie or a slasher movie lol? Watch it!

I think Christopher Robbins LV bag at the beginning cost more then the budget of this movie. It's not boring but it falls under a lot of slasher movie tropes and I was kinda let down. I thought that this could be a good idea for a horror movie but it was held back by it being very low budget and the dialogue between characters was comedically bad the cgi is hilarious. I also thought it was kind of funny that Winnie the Pooh and piglet had beer belly's. The short animations where actually pretty well done but owl and rabbit never made an appearance after that. Maybe there saving them for the sequel if your looking for a goofy horror movie this is a good choice.

review_title: Fun, Not Bad but not exactly good either
review_detailed_main: The very beginning, the intro, of the movie is fantastic. If you went to see this movie in theaters, the beginning gives you everything you want. Then the story gets a little lost for a good half hour to 45 minutes but finds itself in back half of the film. I did expect a horror movie about Winnie the Pooh to poke more fun at itself. It's more of a Holloween movie than a Jason or Evil Dead. But for a movie with a budget of only $15,000, they did a hell of a job. The biggest let down is, without spoilers, the movie feels like it's setting its self up for a final reveal (if you've ever read Winnie the Pooh) but doesn't deliver. If the reveal I was hoping for happened at the end, it would have been an easy 7 but its a solid 5 stars without it.

This is one of the worst movies I have ever seen. Only not too bad thing that came out of it was a good laugh. Not because it was a well done movie, however because the acting was absolutely horrendous, you couldn't do anything but laugh. Definetely wouldn't recommend this movie to anybody. Hooorible acting, very bad plot, and made little to no sense. Very hard watch, I think I got brain damage from all the frustration. Booooooo. Not a very memorable movie. And I can never look at Winnie the Pooh the same way anymore. It has now ruined my childhood. Traumatised and scarred for life however, not from the "scary" scenes, but from the complete lack of quality throughout the whole movie.

review_title: Possibly the worst movie of 2023. The biggest piece of garbage I've ever had the pleasure of watching
review_detailed_main:
This movie was as bad as a Taco Bell bathroom. I was actually excited and had high hopes for this movie when I first heard about it. I thought it would be some dumb, fun, cheesy 80s like slasher. But all that crashing down like a house of cards when I finally was able to see it. The acting is bad, the writing is lazy and stupid and the blood and gore in this movie is just so bad. It's obviously CGI and they don't even tried to hide. But some stuff I did like. Like the music composed for the film. This movie really didn't much potential to be good. But can you at least put some effort into this. And they had CGI BLOOD for crying out loud. Terrifier had many great blood effects their budget was $35,000. But this had $100,000. You telling me they couldn't afford fake blood.?!

But the rest is trash. A.a Milne would be ashamed. The cgi blood is trash. Oh bother.

review_title: Blood and Honey: Destruction of our Childhood
review_detailed_main:
This is the worst slasher movie I have ever had the displeasure of knowing about. Compared to this, Freddy Krueger doesn't seem so scary. You can make movies about guys who haunt peoples' nightmares, you can make movies about someone with a ghost mask on, but making a movie that takes one of the most memorable things from our childhood and completely destroying it is crossing the line! I'd rather watch the Christopher Robin movie than this sh**! This is a disgrace to everything Winnie the Pooh stands for! If it was the creators idea to completely destroy our childhood, mission accomplished.

...

review_title: Watch it for what it is: a movie made through a lapse in copyright protection
review_detailed_main:
'Winnie-The-Pooh: Blood and Honey' tells the story of Christopher Robin (Nikolai Leon) and his pals in the 100 Acre Wood, Pooh (Craig David Dowsett) and Piglet (Chris Cordell). Years after Christopher Robin leaves the wood to go to college, he returns with his wife, Mary (Paula Coiz), but in his absence, Pooh and Piglet have had to find other sources of food, by way of killing humans and cannibalism.

The movie is as silly as the title implies, but was created due to the copyright protections of the original characters lapsing. The acting is fairly poor (you only need girls to scream, apparently) and the script is lacking, but it does deliver on the morbidity and visceral carnage the film promised. The special effects are cheesy, but to be honest, it's not a horribly made film. Cinematography and flow are decent.

Might be worth a watch, if for nothing else, the audactiy of it.

We've seen these kind of horror flick a thousand times over, only this one has a spin on an old fairytale. Again, we have the not so lucky victim buy it, at the start, before the movie title comes up, before some nasty bloody goings on later. I do like the idea, and the gore pic, does have it's moments, some bloody ones, I gorgeously lapped up. Never was I scared, and the film, didn't make me jump, but instigated some unintentional humor, for a gladdened me. One girl of the pact, with the glasses, was an atrocious actress, where for me, was a beneficial atrocity. WTP really doesn't offer that much, but I really loved the piggy costumes. The film was definitely something I didn't.

This is just a very fun and goofy movie. The horror in this film is not meant to be taken seriously. The movie was made as a joke, and I think it perfectly executes on that. Don't come into the movie thinking it's going to be a terrifying movie that's going to make you jump out of your seat or keep you up all night with fear, this movie is going to make you laugh at the absolute ridiculousness of it; turning a beloved childhood character into a horror movie villain who tries to kill people. Overall, the movie perfectly executes on the horror-comedy genre, and I think this movie is best enjoyed when you watch it with your friends, maybe even while eating some honey.

review_title: From a children's story to a horror story
review_detailed_main: After the expiration of the copyright of the Winnie The Pooh books and after a period of waiting, this macabre experiment finally arrives that transforms a children's story into something terrifying. Traditional tales used to be dark and terrifying in their origins until they became infantilized over the years. Now with this film the roles are reversed and it brings us something that is not surprising as it has generated a negative reaction in those who grew up with Winnie The Pooh. This film presents an alternate reality where Pooh and his friends are creatures of flesh and blood and while in the original stories they were stuffed animals that were probably figments of Christopher Robin's imagination. This new imagination presents a different approach to what would happen if Pooh and his friends were flesh and blood beings and if Christopher would not be present to continue caring for them. What we have is an independent film with an evident moderate budget that ends up offering a generic B-movie slasher. The Pooh and Piglet masks give these characters a rather bizarre touch. It uses a lot of practical effects and a little CGI. The truth is that it is an entertaining slasher film for those who like those types of films made in the old fashioned way. It has a very simple story without much to offer about the characters, since many of them are only there to be killed. The death scenes and gore look pretty decent. The script does not seek to give the plot a development, nor to be coherent, but rather to offer a typical slasher without more or less. The movie itself turns out to be bad, but Winnie The Pooh: Blood And Honey is one of those movies that are so bad that they end up being good. My final rating for this movie is a 6/10.

There are movies that ooze charm from their low budget and innocent mistakes but this can't seem to capture that. It has script errors where the cast will say grammar mistakes?? How did no one catch things like that? The costumes look just like that, costumes.

The idea is very fan fic/ creepy pasta. It is interesting to see an IP used like this but I feel like it was a rushed job. They knew the copyright was up and they wanted to strike. I can't blame them for that but they just seem like they didn't put enough thought into it. It was just a very basic horror movie with a Winnie the Pooh skin on it.

Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey is pretty okay with its entertainment, kills, blood, and the story. The story having to do with Christopher Robin having to leave the forest and abandon Winnie the Pooh and the gang for college. Ever since then, Winnie the Pooh and Piglet have felt betrayed and in the need for blood and to be psychopathic killers. They go on to have a killing spree throughout the film ever since they have been betrayed.

Overall, there are some parts I liked and disliked. The parts that I liked were the entertainment value that this is a Winnie the Pooh Horror Parody film. Also, I liked the kills, blood, and gore for being a horror fan. Some parts that I did not like were since that the cast are mainly females that it gets raunchy and overly sexual towards the male demographic audience. Speaking in a male's standpoint that it was just really cheesy. Not just that, but the acting was not that good either. It is a mid-level film of entertainment in my opinion. Lastly, I cannot believe that there is a sequel greenlit coming out soon. I am most likely going to watch it because I just love these horror parody films taken from Hollywood from our childhoods that turn out to be either good or a mess.

The characters went into public domain, and it is as if someone said they wanted to make a slasher movie with the Winnie-the-Pooh characters in the worst possible way. And in this they succeeded. A most unpleasant movie, mostly in the dark. The prologue gives the gist of the story. Christopher Robin, who promised they would always be together, had to leave for college. They were abandoned, starved, ate one of the characters, and turned feral. Piglet has tusks. 5 years later, Christopher Robin returns to 100 Acre Woods with his sweetheart Mary, and she is killed, and he is tortured. Meanwhile, a group of young women rent a home nearby. Maria needs a break, as she was stalked. Doesn't work out well for them, and what is really bad about this is that the women characters are written as they only make bad decisions, they also scream a lot. In a way, that is adding insult to what has already insulted the audience, a terrible movie. Oh, one of the women has a gun. Since this is set in England, that is beyond belief. Even the killings are done badly, with terrible special effects. I don't give one stars easily, but I cannot go any lower on the IMDB rating scale. There are movies so bad they are good. This is not one of those.

review_title: The potential was there but it was never quite reached.
review_detailed_main:
As someone who never had a strong attachment to Winnie the Pooh, even as a child, I can understand the distaste towards this premise; but I still wanted to see it regardless. The film's opening is interesting, but unfortunately after that it becomes less interesting. The college girls are boring and dislikable, and it would've been much better if we focused on Christopher or perhaps an old friend of Christopher who comes looking for him after the beginning.

The kills are probably the best part of this movie, and they were fun to watch but I would've liked a more interesting plot to engage in. Winnie and Piglett look all right, it's explained that there animal hybrids, I think, all though some of Pooh's... abilities are a little questionable.

I will say I was entertained, the climax is interesting, a little confusing at first, but I liked it. If a sequel comes I'll give it a crack, but make it more centered and personnel, don't add random teenagers into the mix.
