For that I found it a really enjoyable silly dark romp. The narrative begining was out of place and unnecessary but I see what they tried to do with the original kids book material. I got more than I expected, it delivered more than just camp and backstory like malignant, didn't pretend to have twists, and didn't set out to be a cinematic gem. This movie simply is what it is and I enjoyed that. I'm looking forward to a rewatch when it's available for purchase.

review_title: Spoiler-free review winnie the pooh: blood and honey
review_detailed_main: To be honest, i like the idea and it's pretty fun/entertaining to watch. I'll start with the good things: i honestly think that the costume is pretty badass and looks dope. The cinematography was actually pretty decent. I also really like the beginning that they're telling us how he started killing people. The kills were actually pretty creative and gory. The movie is so silly that it's just fun to watch and that's just my opinion. Now the bad stuff: the acting is cringe and bad, but it like didn't bother me or someting. This is like the kind of movie where the characters make the dumbest decisions. We need more plot in the movie, i mean it's the same the whole time: winnie the pooh is mad and goes around and kils people. Another stupid thing like how can winnie drive??? I also think that this movie would be better if all the friends from winnie would be in it and that they killed some people to. Overall it's just a silly movie but it's fun so i give it 3/5.

"Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey" is a disappointing addition to the beloved franchise,

One of the film's major flaws is its departure from the lighthearted and whimsical tone that fans of the franchise have come to love. Instead of the gentle adventures and endearing friendships that defined the original stories, "Blood and Honey" presents a dark and unsettling narrative that feels out of place in the Hundred Acre Wood.

The decision to introduce themes of violence and conflict into the world of Winnie the Pooh is jarring and unnecessary, undermining the innocence and simplicity that made the original stories so beloved. From bloody battles between the Hundred Acre Wood inhabitants to scenes of graphic violence, the film takes a dark and disturbing turn that is sure to leave audiences feeling uncomfortable.

Furthermore, the characters themselves feel unrecognizable in this gritty reinterpretation. Winnie the Pooh, once known for his gentle nature and love of honey, is transformed into a serial killer with his friend Piglet, are stripped of their lovable qualities, replaced with one-dimensional caricatures devoid of the charm that endeared them to audiences for generations.

In addition to its misguided tone and characterizations, "Blood and Honey" suffers from a lackluster plot that fails to engage or captivate. The story meanders aimlessly from one violent encounter to the next, lacking the heart and depth that defined the original tales. With little emotional resonance or narrative cohesion, the film struggles to hold the audience's attention, ultimately feeling like a hollow and forgettable addition to the Winnie the Pooh canon.

Overall, "Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey" is a misguided and disappointing departure from the beloved franchise. With its dark and unsettling tone, one-dimensional characters, and lackluster plot, the film fails to capture the magic of the original stories, leaving audiences longing for the simpler and sweeter adventures of the Hundred Acre Wood.

review_title: It's Alright If you Give it A shot!
review_detailed_main: To be honest, This character based movie was not that great, but if you really give it a shot, you will like it: it has a lot of things like "white girl acting" and a BUNCH of brutal gore and very fake blood (CGI) (also a little bit of nudity which I'm not a big fan of AT ALL) which some of these things make the movie ACTUALLY be good, but there are alot of negitive things that people don't like. No wonder is so over-hated, and plus. It's pretty fun and funny ! (Sorry if my review doesn't make any sense lol)

review_title: Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey
review_detailed_main: Now don't judge. You mustn't judge. If you do this will come across as the most atrocious piece of cinema since "Mesa of Lost Women" (1953). "Christopher Robin" (Nikolai Leon) is taking his fiancee back to the wood in which he played with "Pooh", "Piglet", "Eyeore" etc. As a child. What he doesn't appreciate, though, is that in the intervening years things got tough for his erstwhile friends. They couldn't fend for themselves, and were reduced to cannibalism to survive.... Aside from altering the balance of their tiny mids, this also instilled in "Pooh" and "Piglet" a grim and determined need for vengeance. What now ensues is hilarious. What ever budget there was must have been spent on gin for the cast: the costumes and lighting are pretty dreadful and the script - well that is almost as bad as the acting. Leon is quite easy on the eye, but the sight of him being whipped to within an inch of his life with the tail of "Eyeore" by a large man in an ill-fitting yellow bear suit whose mouth was oozing honey like a drooling bairn just has to be seen. Cinema can be too earnest and worthy at times, and I think this is the perfect recalibration for that - it is certainly neither, nor is it a film you will ever (want to) remember after you've seen it. Still, the cinema was packed and there was laughter a-plenty throughout the eighty minutes or so this risible drivel lasted. It could easily be a school project - nothing here is of an higher standard, and it did make me squirm at times as the 1970s "Doctor Who" special effects department came back to life - but I didn't hate it.

review_title: Just a slasher with people in masks
review_detailed_main: If you watch this movie because it has Winnie the Pooh and you think it would be cool to see how that comes across in horror, I think you'll be disappointed. That's what brought me in! First off, there's not really much Winnie the Pooh as you know it beyond a quick backstory done with animated sketches. Other than that, this is just your run of the mill slasher movie. Nothing really new. The only Winnie the Pooh characters are Pooh and Piglet. Piglet is unrecognizable as piglet. I guess Winnie the Pooh is himself, but honestly, I'm not sure I'd know he was Winnie the Pooh if it wasn't in the title. I have a few issues with this move. First, it obvious they just used Winnie the Pooh so that people would watch the movie. Otherwise, it would just be another one of the hundreds of indy slasher movies out there to watch. Winnie and Piglet are just people in masks, so I had to keep reminding myself they were supposed to be themselves instead of men with masks on, but that was hard to do. What's next, a sequel for Cujo with Scooby Doo? I think this would have at least been more entertaining if they had all of the characters instead of just Winnie and Piglet.

I think they made it to be stupid but added all the gore and body count to get those fans. Sad, because the idea could have been a REALLY good story instead of being so mind numbingly bad. The actors TRIED but there just wasn't a plot or a story.

I was all excited to watch this and sadly I did. The IDEA is a million dollar idea.... the story being told is NOT. It's like they had this great idea and handed it to kids who all they could think about was how bloody and how many dead can we fit into it.

Again, the actors themselves can't be judged by this movie alone. There was NOTHING in the story that could elicit any amount of interest or care. BUT it was obvious they TRIED.

What was the author and director trying to even convey in this movie? That meat is murder? That animals can be trained to be psychotic serial killers and masochists?

In all honesty I'd spend the time banging my head on the wall because eventually I would either knock myself out OR the pain would stop but with this movie, the pain just never ends.

TBH I don't even know why I watched the whole movie, too tired to change shows or I kept thinking it HAD to get better, when in fact it just sank deeper.

review_title: A good ide with a bad execution
review_detailed_main:
I fell that the movie in its core is a good ide and I like it, but the editing is more really really bad and the camrea work is the most scary part of the movie.

Even though I said I like the core consept the plot is also really underdevelopte and I found myself many time just think "where did that come from?" or "who is that?"

The movie also suffers from bad acting prefomance and bad caracters in generall who in the movie seems really stupid and I found myself think many times how easely certain parts could have been avoided

But now to a part I actully liked, I think the ide of trying to give pooh a shread of humanity was a good ide that they unfortanetly did not develop enough just like the rest of the movie.

I understand they rushed this once the rights went public, but couldn't they have saved just a few more weeks of their allowance to buy masks anywhere other than the Dollar Store?

I love so-bad, it's-good and unintentionally hilarious movies like The Room, Birdemic and Troll 2. With this getting almost zero stars from the get-go, I just had to see it. Only, I didn't want to pay $19.99 for a mere rental and had to wait until this finally dropped to $4.99. (Still too much to pay.)

Winnie the Drool and Pigless terrorize some girls at a cabin. That's the non-spoilery gist. But, think: The youths took a Wrong Turn from the Texas Chain Saw Massacre on Halloween to use their Hatchet against Bebop.

There's tons wrong with the script, such as they never speak again until the plot needs them to. Also, there's a 5-year time jump post-cold-open and our "hero" can't seem to remember places he had visited his entire life up to half-a-decade ago. Really? And, there are four remaining Pooh characters and yet two completely disappear never to be heard of again. But, what can you expect. This 100% looked like an experimental Film School Thesis from a C+ student. So many shots were sooo artsy.

And when I say those masks look bad, NO ONE in this cast or crew gave a blank about making them look anything but a fifty-cent rubber Halloween mask. This movie would've been 10x better had the killers just be humans with cheap masks on. They just had to make them "real-life" animal/human hybrids...for reasons. And don't get me started on the CGI...

What I can say that's positive: I loved the cold/cartoonish opening and new backstory. Quite creative. But, then the movie began. Sigh.

Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey isn't the worst movie I've ever seen and sadly I was kinda hoping for it to be. I really thought this was gonna be Jeepers Creepers: Reborn-bad. Nope. Not even in the same ball field.

But is it even so-so? No and so completely bland and unremarkable, it's not recommended. Those masks alone make this movie just so dumb. I only laughed once or twice. Don't ask me if that was the movie's intention or not. Haven't a clue.

***

Final Thoughts: This reminded me of that Disneyland horror flick, Escape from Tomorrow. I understand some people like that movie. I couldn't stand it, at all. Way worse than this movie. So, see? Lower your expectations, like I had for Winnie the Pooh's first foray into horror and it's not the worst of the worst.

review_title: Excellent Flat Out Horror.. Featuring "Winnie the Pooh"
review_detailed_main:
"Winnie the Pooh -- Blood and Honey" will probably shock a lot of viewers, given it is being characterized in the media as a "fun horror flick with Winnie the Pooh." Fact is, it's a pretty shocking, deadly serious slasher movie with a hefty dollop of graphic violence.

In a cartoon prologue, we get the "slasher event" that kicks off the horror -- in this case, Christopher Robbins leaving his friends at "100 Aker Wood." Unable the fend for themselves, they turn feral and become filled with rage. And when Christopher returns five years later he finds things have changed... a lot. At the same time, a woman named Maria is dealing with a stalker issue, and so she invites five of her friends to get away from the city. But unfortunately for them, they chose to go to a house at the edge of "100 Aker Wood"...

People who go to "Winnie the Pooh -- Blood and Honey" expecting a comedy or parody or light entertainment are going to be stunned. This movie is bleak and nihilistic and takes its scares and kills seriously. The violence is graphic and in your face. There isn't a laugh or joke of "wink to the audience" in the entire film.

Not to say that's bad -- quite the contrary. It's a fine addition to the horror genre, you just need to know what you're getting into. At the showing I went to, I sat in front of a group that was desperate for this to be a comedy, a couple of times they went into very forced laughter at a non-funny sequence and then were almost immediately stunned into silence.

The filmmakers took a risk -- the easy way is to make this a silly, lame "horror comedy." Making this a flat-out horror film took guts and the result is worth it. It's clearly set up for a sequel (the end credits proudly say "Winnie the Pooh Will Return") and we can all look forward to it. Definitely worth checking out for horror fans!

review_title: A film so random, it's unbelievable.
review_detailed_main:
It's difficult to say whether this film is twisted genius or a pile of crap.

I'm still deciding but whatever I decide I enjoyed it immensely. Big geezers dressed in questionable masks channelling beloved characters killing people is certainly a sight to behold.

Witness one of kid's books most popular characters ripping off a girl's top revealing the obvious. It's certainly not high art but well made considering it was probably made for about a fiver.

There's a sequel coming and I may be possibly one of a few who will impatiently wait for more carnage.

God bless the public domain and god bless the film makers for delivering something so tasteless.

review_title: I am sure it could be worse..
review_detailed_main: I am not really sure how, but it could be worse... They could have used prosthetics instead of cheap rubber masks, real actors would have helped, as would have a real script.. The premise of the story is not bad.. It is actually good and could worked if they had put some effort and maybe a little bit of money into it. I get it. It's all about the shock value of a horror movie based on the beloved children's book, but that ia exactly why if you're going to do something that's supposed to shock and destroy our childhood memories of Pooh and the gang, do it right, or don't do it at all! That's what I think.

review_title: Overall weird and doesn't meet expectations
review_detailed_main: Honestly if they would've made it more of a funny parody slasher like it should've been it would've been great. However they didn't do that they took it way too serious. They went for pure shock factor hoping to wow the audience with the graphic and gruesome deaths. Pooh doesn't look too bad, not great but not bad. Piglet on the other hand looks horrible. They introduce Christopher robin right away but he ends up being a side character for the whole movie with hardly any contribution until the end. The characters we're supposed to care about are weird and make the same dumb mistakes every horror movie character does. Would've been better if they'd have at least had some intelligence and run away from the killer but a few kills were just because they're stupid. Overall one of those movies you leave saying wtf. Not great by any means but not the worst thing I've ever seen.

review_title: IT WAS SO BAD! DO NOT WASTE UR TIME WATCHING THIS MOVIE
review_detailed_main: Who in their right mind decide to create a movie THIS BAD? It was sooo bad that I almost ended up crying because of how stressed I was and how bad the movie was,I will never forgive this movie for wasting my time! PLEASE DO NOT WASTE UR TIME WATCHING THIS MOVIE! I still don't understand why they did a 2nd movie when the 1st one was sooo bad I really can't describe how bad it was if I could give it 0 stars I would definitely, it didn't only make me cry because of how bad it was but my cousin too,the movie was soooo stupid and cringe that I had to take breaks to watch that stupid ass movie! ----

After seeing the backlash from critics and fans alike, expectations were low. This film is a retelling of the children's novel Winnie the Pooh but in an R rated horror twist.

What makes this film rather poor is that we don't know much about the women lead characters. At times it was difficult in understanding them given their UK accents. Barely remembered any of their names- which is not a good sign. Overall they were just generic and after a point we didn't care for their eventual deaths.

With a low budget, this film feels a little rushed but that's expected.

There are some decent gory and bloody kills but a majority of what occurs has happened in slasher films before.

Also the film takes itself too serious. Perhaps they should have went for a more campy and funny tone. No memorable dialogue, no witty or clever humor. Everything was predictable. Very generic standard thriller.

One positive is the appearance of Winnie the Pooh (the mask looks great). Piglet looks more deformed and looks more like a boar. It's mask wasn't pink enough.

review_title: Shocking, but because it's so bad
review_detailed_main:
Maybe had half a chance with some of the kill scenes that were a decent take on 80s horrors. If it's your thing, a nice bit if gore.

Sadly, the acting and script put paid to that and ruined any chance it had.

Just utter stupidity that made no sense in what the 'actors' had to do. You'll find yourself laughing at it but sadly in areas that weren't meant to be laughed at.

Some money spent on on the sets, but a possibly fun horror just ruined by the script and the acting, another wot cud have been movie.

AA Milne may return in the sequel after his heart restarts from spinning in his grave from this.

After A. A. Milne's 1926 novel of Winnie the Pooh entered the public domain there are lots of opportunities for people to make their own kinds of adaptations of this story, so making a horror movie off this character is overall a weird idea, but depending on what you do with it you could make something at least interesting or entertaining to watch; after watching this movie, I will say that this is a bit worse than what I thought this low budget movie was going to be. In the horror film adaptation Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey (2023) there are bad performances, bland characters, ok cinematography, harmful effects, unconvincing looking killers, brutal kills with horror movie tropes you have seen before, and an awful script with just cringe worthy lines of dialogue; what was the dumbest thing was that the film takes itself too seriously with this concept, instead of having fun with the concept and being aware of what it is.

All the lead girl characters are dumb, bland, and disposable people with bad performances that you could care less about, with there also being other random side girl characters who show up just to get killed off later in the film, along with them getting killed off easily and doing dumb things that gets themselves killed; the only character depth you get is that one of the girls had a traumatic past involving a creeper, which is why this group of characters are on a trip to this house in the woods, but it has little to do with anything so I did not care. Winnie the Pooh and Piglet in this are setup as anthropomorphic creatures which is why they look like they do, but the bad masks that look like they just found random masks online that were close enough to what the characters looked like, and their motivation for going feral makes sense despite sounding like a dumb reason; also, Winnie the Pooh gets a random ability near the climax of the film that was not setup at all, with him also being questionably very strong to kill people. Lastly, you have an awful performance from the actor playing Christopher Robin, with him barely being in the film except in the beginning, somewhere in the middle, and in the ending; the setup is that he leaves them alone for many years, and it makes Winnie the Pooh and everyone feral and mad at him.

Though the kills in the movie are brutal and bloody, it starts out with some uses of practical blood effects then it uses bad CGI blood effects that was a bit distracting with every kill, along with there being weird looking CGI to just make Winnie the Pooh's face/mask change expressions and have his mouth open and close; the script for this movie was bad, like it needed to be rewritten or tweaked a bit more to make the dialogue better because it involves certain characters repeating themselves a lot to saying the most bland and dumb things. The movie starts with a quick backstory to setup what this movie is about, and at first, I thought it could work but after that it got worse with it leading to a rushed third act climax and an ending that does not feel like an ending and feels more like it just stopped; this movie took itself too seriously despite having an occasional that was a little entertaining or funny, but the only thing that was good enough was the cinematography with its nice shots of the woods and the house they stay in, despite there also being some bad editing throughout the film.

The film Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey (2023) there are bad performances, bland characters, ok cinematography, harmful effects, unconvincing looking killers, brutal kills with horror movie tropes you have seen before, fine cinematography, bad editing, and an awful script with just cringe worthy lines of dialogue; what was the dumbest thing was that the film takes itself too seriously with this concept and the bare minimum of what you could do with this idea, instead of having fun with it. I will admit that the idea could have worked and that there was effort put into this film by the director, but it did not work out that well which is why I am obviously not going to recommend this; if you want to check this movie out because of the concept, go ahead, but I still think this movie is definitely worth skipping.

I don't think I would really call this horror. It seems more like a gory comedy and I'm kinda here for it. Don't want if you want a really scary movie, it's a good first scary movie though lol. It's a really great idea, having the whole group turn evil but it was executed very poorly. Also, something that I noticed what that only Winnie, piglet, and eeyore In the movie, but rabbit and roo just kinda disappeared. The outfits too. Winnie was not in his iconic red shirt. A red flannel with overalls on!! Sound effects also sucked in some areas. Overall, glad I watched it, wasn't scary, but it was really funny.

review_title: Really fun film with some minor issues.
review_detailed_main:
This film utilises some expected tropes from the genre, jump scares, mute unbeatable killer, back lighting and smoke, questionable motives etc.

All the elements of a good horror are present, atmospheric scenery, great sets, well chosen locations, highly competent cinematography, realistic props, a great soundtrack and sadistic killers!

I found the level of humour to be good, some of the tongue in cheek moments including Pooh having the abilities of a bear despite not having any visible claws. It's just fun!

Unfortunately the opening is a little flat and doesn't really show the actors at their best, the guy who plays Christopher really comes into his own later in the story.

The killing methods were varied and inventive with some interesting setups being paid off later.

To achieve a film of this level of polish in ten days, means sacrificing multiple takes. Which is probably the reason the performance can be a little wooden at times. It's still very enjoyable though, and I had the most fun watching a film I've had in a while!

With a decent budget allocated to the announced sequel, I have high hopes the minor issues will be ironed out and we'll have a new horror series with many more films to be made.

Anyone who has rated this 1 star is acting in bad faith, there are a lot of strong elements that make this enjoyable and any horror fan should find this entertaining. I will be watching this again in the future and look forward to the sequel.

review_title: Hmm. What a cheap way to cash in.
review_detailed_main:
I can only imagine the scene when this script got pitched.

It's enough to make my skin crawl at the depths some people will go to to turn a buck. No class, no respect, no decency. Just pure dollar signs.

Had the author decided to try and write something along the lines of Cain and Abel clearly must've engaged in fornication with Eve, their mother, I wonder if the main financiers would've backed it. I doubt it. It says as much about them as it does about the English author. But hey, nothing ever stopped a son of Abraham from knocking out a good Christmas tune.

I truly hope that this film loses as much money as possible for all stakeholders..

review_title: What the hell did I just watch?

review_detailed_main: It has its moments. Coming for someone who grew up on Winnie the pooh and friends, i was not going into the expecting the lovable bare we all know. But i was expecting to get scared at least a little. This movie definitely could have been worse but it could have been a lot better. It reminds me of those short stories on YouTube. No plot and really really poor acting. I watched four people leave the theater. It was not worth the money and i will never watch it again. But with the understanding that the budget was around 100,000, i've seen much worse. Overall, if you do plan on watching the movie, i would wait for it to be free somewhere, not worth the money in anyway. 3/10.

Well it's not supposed to be good. I had low expectations and they were almost met. Once the novelty of Mr pooh wore off they had to do something to hold our attention and didn't really seem to try. They could have packed in more death gore horror and nudity to make it a slasher or spent an extra 20 bucks so that the masks could speak which would have been nice.

So if ya wanna watch something pointless get some friends around to make fun of it. This will not hold your attention on its own.

It's fun but they could have tried a lot harder... or any really. I'm looking forward to Heathcliff vs Garfield Mondays are the worst.

review_title: Nice start, but gets lost in the woods
review_detailed_main:
This could have been so much better. I originally had no plan of ever watching it, but it was on Peacock and I wanted to watch something that I could easily turn off if I needed to go somewhere. It wasn't great, but it had its moments.

The story they set up in the beginning is actually really cool. The idea of the characters losing all sense of humanity after being abandoned and having to eat one of their own for survival had me pretty hooked in the beginning. It was done through illustration, and it was an overall very solid beginning to a movie.

The problem is that it very quickly devolves into a boring slasher, where two characters just show up and murder people. They don't even explain where the rest of the characters are. It is just Pooh and Piglet walking around killing people. Where's rabbit? Where's Roo? Also, there is no real emotional attachment to any of the characters. They literally just exist to be killed by Winnie the Pooh. All the primary victims being women also feels a little weird. Men seem to only die if they get in the way of the killing of the women.

Every once in a while, they would try to delve into the original story line of abandonment, but every time, it is quickly pushed out of the way so that someone can be killed with a sledge hammer. It seems like they had a really solid idea, but then wanted to be the first ones to release a Pooh horror movie after it went public domain, so they just said, "f it, who has the time to flesh out this story, let's just make them murder everyone."

This concept could have been fun and dark and thoughtful, but instead it is just a very generic slasher film. A silent killer that looks like Winnie the Pooh but could very easily be any silent killer. It was filmed well though, so that is another plus I guess. At least now I can say that I watched it. I don't plan on ever watching it again, but I don't feel as if it was a waste of time watching it.

More than being scary, this movie is creepy. Other than that, it's a slasher. A very formulaic slasher. The twist is that the killers are these childhood story characters, but at the end of the day it's a slasher that happens at a cabin in the woods. The set pieces are kinda cool, though, and the gore is quite good.

I think the original idea is very creative, but the execution lacks a little originality. There are a lot of nods to other movies of the genre, but they are done in a way thay you can't really tell if it's a homage or just a borrowed idea.

I hope that for the sequel they work a little on the acting direction, we are not on the 80's anymore.

review_title: Could have been great with a more imaginative script
review_detailed_main:
Trust me when I tell you that I actually really, really, really wanted to like the Winnie-the-Pooh slasher movie. I gave it about as fair of a shake as I could and I have to say-it's a missed opportunity on just about every level. Using such a beloved, universally heartwarming series as fodder for a creepy horror film could have been a grand slam with imaginative subversions of the classic story, but this really just wasn't it. It really just felt like a cheap slasher movie where the killers looked like adult men wearing bear and pig masks. I will say though, the acting was better than I expected across the boards and the storybook opening sequence was pretty fun. Everything else, though, left a lot to be desired.

I look forward to more clever public domain uses of Winnie-the-Pooh in the future and will almost certainly skip this film's sequel.

If you're looking this movie up, you've probably already decided whether you want to watch it or not.

How to describe it? Hmmm.

Imagine Sharknado or VelociPastor making a sex tape with every slasher movie ever made, filmed by Ticket and Dale and leaving your childhood behind as a giant wet spot.

It's that good. Or that bad, depending on your perspective.

There's basically no plot, as befits an heir to the Halloween or Friday the Thirteenth legacies, the blood effects are much better than I expected on the budget they had, and the references to other slasher flicks are not overly bold and in your face. They're ax-ually (Sorry) subtle enough that I'm pretty sure the rest of the audience was laughing with them like I was. There's very little dialogue and what there is is not awful. The acting is standard for the type of movie and not Tommy Wiseau bad.

It's bloody, which is to be expected and is probably best for fans of the genre, but it's far more amusing than most. I am definitely going to acquire a copy of this when it gets to home video.

And why only 9 stars? The masks on Pooh and Piglet are pretty bad. Maybe with the money this brings in, the sequel will have better.

I am totally there for that.

You can be sure that I'm a well versed horror fanatic. With that said, this is actually a worthwhile movie for the true select few. Me being one of them.

In the same category as the terrifier films, Winnie the Pooh blood and honey tries to be next level disturbing. It honestly is. Where terrifier fills with blood and gore, this movie fills with atmosphere, dread, and unforgivingness. This movie offers some truly haunting imagery and horrific sequences. The storyline is so unique and dark that it adds such a layer of menace to Winnie the Pooh and Piglett. The opening sequence is so haunting when Winnie and piglett are slowly closing in on Christopher robin, and the scene when the girl sees Winnie in the woods and he just starts clog stomping towards her all crazy.. truly scary. This is a real horror movie with no strings atrached. It's cheap yes but it makes it all the more raw for that reason. This is the superior film between this and terrifier. I really enjoyed it, sorry most of you did not. Go watch ur mainstream blockbusters and leave these types of movies to the truest in the community.

Some of the gore/torture scenes were genuinely creative, and it did disturb me a little. But overall the movie relied just on the "Hey, look it's a character you know and love being evil, weird huh?" way too much. There wasn't a single point where I was scared or invested in the story at all. The movie could've leaned into the weird premise so heavily that it could've been good. But it was just a cookie cutter slasher with Winnie the Pooh frosting on top. So nah it wasn't good.

The atmosphere is paper thin. The style was bland and dull, not to mention the terrible writing that just plain sucks.

Yeah, the film isn't creative, and it doesn't have any fun with the idea. It's just disappointing.

I dont recommend it.

review_title: This film is bad at its worst

review_detailed_main: To be fair I was not expecting this movie to be taken seriously for one second. The idea of two of the most lovable childhood characters turning psychotic and going on a rampage is obviously something that people expect to laugh, not scream, at. Overall, though, the movie is hard to understand, even with the ridiculous sounding idea. I expected to be able to laugh at the ridiculously over-the-top style and perhaps weak effects and did indeed see some moments done so "badly" that it was almost hysterical. As someone who watches cheesy horror movies to laugh, I can tell you that this really belongs in its own special group. I can't necessarily say that I liked this movie, but I could never say that I hated it. Everything in it was so overdone that it was hilarious when you look back at it. I think it would have been better if they had done with zombie versions of the animals, though.

review_title: Well that was definitely a.. umm movie
review_detailed_main:
Look I didn't hate it but it was pretty stupid for a horror..

I went to the movies to see it and every was laughing at some of the stupid parts...

The concept was ok but there wasn't a real story line and it went pretty quickly.. felt like just a touch over an hour.

The characters didn't really grow or have any real meaning or development. I couldn't recall any of their names by the end of it.

I also didn't like how at the end they said Pooh will be back... expecting there will be a second movie.. considering the quality of the 1st one. I think they would have been better off just killing Christopher.

And one last thing what happened to tiga or rabbit?? No real explanation.

Or "How To Kill A Childrens Story Loved by BILLIONS".

Or "How to Epitomize The Decline of Modern Times"

Cause lets face it: Modern Times kinda suck and have for a good number of years, going back into the 2010s. Yet despite the abject failure of much of the world, humanity, and entertainment in general in most genres and franchises, this movie at least set out to fulfill its promise of being a slasher revolving around the titular character. THat being said, it wasnt terrible tbh.

The location was a fairly nice track of wilderness, the masks worn by the "animals/killers" were actually decent. Oh and I didnt really notice any CGI It was all practical affects aside from some dripping blood or other effects here and there.

IT really stuck to the mythos of the beloved childrens characters for the most part, and the sets they constructed seemed like they could have just been peoples camping grounds in their backyard, as much as where the killer animals dwelt. The story in theory is haunting and disturbing, not just for spitting int he faces and collective memories of a cherished, pristine, once untouchable franchise, but the way they explained the "WHY" of the film.

The lighting was good, especially at night, the flame effects and a lot of the gore and makeup was spot on. Honestly I give a lot of props to most of the actors like the dude that plays Christopher Robin, Pooh, and some of the gals and others in the movie. IT was basically just about killing innocence, but wow did it go the full 9 yards to do so.

If not for the parts of me that were kinda offended by the thought of Pooh BEar and Piglet being murderous, rampaging, stalker eaters of people, I might have given this a halr score or more higher rating. As it stands, its a 4.5 for what they did to poor Winniw The Pooh. An where the hell was Tigger and Owl?

Pooh was HUN-GRY FFS lol 4.5/10 ( but again might have been a 5.5 for the acting which was ok, but thos effects were pretty enjoyable, as was the scene craft and props.) MAKE A SEQUEL! B MOVIES ARE BACK! Lol ( Or is this what I call a "C Movie"? Hmm) Oh Bother... :P Happy Shocktober.

review_title: Never really subverts the source material like it should have.
I don't mind the low budget
review_detailed_main:
That the movie could be filmed and completed in 8 days is amazing. I don't mind the low budget. I don't mind the costumes. I don't mind the bad acting. I don't mind the dodgy camera work. This was an independent movie made by amateurs. I don't mind the dodgy sound work.

What I do mind is the terrible script. The animated sequence says something about Pooh and Piglet swearing to never again speak to humans, and yet they seem to do precisely that to one of the prisoners.

One scene has a woman with a gun staring down at Pooh. Hey idiot: You have a gun, and a clear shot at a barely moving target--SHOOT! No? Well after that, you deserve to die, and so does everyone else for being your friend. (That's the logic of the movie) We have no idea who the humans are. We get a little detail about one of the women having had a stalker, but that's it. The others are... ??? No clue.

The information in the intro animation is almost completely repeated by the dialog in the first scene, so... why do we need the same thing twice in rapid succession? It's almost like they showed it to someone, and their test audience said "I don't understand. Why are they feral?" and so the animation was added to front-end and reinforce the set-up.

All kinds of logic flaws in the movie make what could have been a fun indi movie and make it yet another stupid indi movie. Honestly, they just needed to fix the script!

This movie wasn't meant to be any kind of cinematic greatness. It's a low budget horror flick. Pooh and Piglet are clearly two grown ass men wearing a bear and hog mask. It's a ridiculously silly concept.

I'm shocked that others were shocked by how bad it was. It just seems like the kind of movie that's meant to be bad. I went into it knowing it would be bad.

Overall, the kills were fun and gruesome. The CGI was a bit too obvious in a few kill scenes but it worked well enough. Acting was meh but since they basically just ran around screaming, it wasn't too distracting.

It's watchable, IMO. If you're looking for mindless kills with bad costumes, it's a fun watch.

Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey is a thrilling and heartwarming adventure that me and my 7 year old son loved! The film follows Pooh and his friends as they face a mysterious threat that puts their home and lives in danger. Along the way, they discover secrets about their past, their relationships, and their true selves. The film is a masterful blend of humor, action, drama, and nostalgia that will appeal to children of all ages.

The acting is stunning, the sets are superb, and the soundtrack is memorable. Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey is a must-see for anyone who loves Pooh and his pals. It is a rare gem that manages to be both faithful to the original stories and innovative in its own right.

It is a rare gem that will be beloved and talked about for ages to come.

review_title: Is it great? No. Is it a good time? Yes.
review_detailed_main: Movies such as these aren't made to be good. It's like turning on Toxic Avenger and expecting an Oscar nominated film and getting... well... Toxic Avenger. I had absolutely no delusions of grandeur for this film. None whatsoever. Nevertheless, it was fun to watch. The concept of twisting favorite childhood characters into something murderous and terrifying is definitely fun and worth watching. The kills aren't anything terribly creative, but instead of being fast and shocking, they're slow and deliberate which adds to the overall brutality. In essence, don't watch it if you're an overt snob or if you're expecting something revolutionary. I do recommend watching it if you're a fan of things like Roger Corman and Lloyd Kaufman films.

review_title: Was good here and there, but too much for an R rated movie
It's ok but wtf kinda ending was that
review_detailed_main: I went into this movie expecting it to be bad just from all the reviews but it wasn't as bad as I thought it was gonna be, lots of stupid parts where you're just shaking your head, the worst is the ending, there is no ending, it just ends. The kills were brutal, which is what I want from a slasher, and when I looked into the cast online it showed tigger and rabbit being in it but they were not, that was disappointing cause I was waiting for tigger the whole movie. This movie had so much potential to be one of the greats but it was just ok, I might watch it again in the future, or if there's a sequel I'll probably check it out.

Better than the 2.9 it currently stands at.

Great idea, it's all about our childhood fairytale characters, with a hills have eyes twist of course.

More really could have been done. The plot was decent, just sketchy and not helped by diabolical acting.

It was a good old fashioned slasher flick to be fair.

I read it was a $100000 budget and filmed over 10 days. The actors must have only got a few grand each and it supposedly grossed $5 million. Not a bad return.....for the money people and for them it was a result.

Maybe entice better actors with a royalties payment, even 1% each for the main cast woulda been a great return.

This movie is no fun. It isn't entertaining in any way. It is a terrible attempt at telling a story and an even worse example of movie making. It has to be one of the worst looking films ever shot with every scene glazed in the most unappealing filter available. As far as the plot, it involves some girls getting stalked by Winnie the Pooh and Piglet, who are giant, indestructible man-like butchers. There are some kills, and each one is just about as pedestrian as possible. The only one that stands out involves a car and it is more silly than anything. I would urge anyone who has any curiosity about this movie to avoid it completely. There is nothing to gain by having seen it.

review_title: It's a good bad movie night film
review_detailed_main:
Okay, honest opinion here:

If you're expecting MCU, Warner Brothers quality horror movie, you will be disappointed because as some have already reviewed the filming isn't the best and it is low budget.

That being said, take into consideration that this is a small group of unknown actors who took a well known childhood classic and gave it a horror twist and frankly, I think they did a nice job with it. Pooh's appearance while silly, has an unsettling appearance, they give a few explanation as to why they go feral as well as to why Christopher befriended them and wants to believe that they can still be friends, there were some good gory kills (some a little silly but again, it's a low budget film and I've seen some awful death scenes before and I think they did a good job), and generally I think they did a good job keeping a cohesive story from start to finish, which is often a problem that happens with many low budget horrors. And personally, I love how Pooh only talks once in the movie so that we aren't bombarded with poor impressions of Winnie's voice, but instead have a raspy voice which fits the "They swore to never speak again".

So while this isn't a movie for everyone, I don't think it's awful. It's not the most amazing, but for what they had to work with, I think it's a fun little campy movie to watch on a night where you kind of just want to make your own Rifftrack of it.

The year is 2023 - B grade movies are expected to have bad actors, bad effects and a bad story telling, it's all here. The prologue sets up the movie awesomely, then the budget ran out and the remaining hour and 20 minutes (roughly) is what you have to sit through. As I said before, it's 2023, a better effort should have been made with this adaptation of Winnie the Pooh into the horror genre. Do we want to see this? Hell yeah, if it's done right, there's a good chance that it will become good enough for a multi-movie horror fest. Forget a sequel to this, just start a fresh with a bigger budget. Would I recommend this, not really.

In 100 Acre Wood, Christopher Robin (Nikolai Leon) had allowed the animals to deform over the years and abandoned them to attend college. They starved and ate Eeyore. They vow to return to their animalistic nature with their hatred of humans especially Christopher Robin. After five years, he returns with his wife after gaining some success writing about his animal friends. They are attacked by his old friends. Maria and her girlfriends are spending time at a nearby cabin after she experienced some creepy stalking. They and others become targets for the disturbing group.

This starts with a funny horror idea, but it delivers very little else. One could watch the first five minutes and that's the best of the movie. It has nothing left after that. It has no imagination. It tries to do a bunch of bloody kills. The characters aren't interesting or fun. They should have done it this way. Christopher Robin reads in the news that people are brutally killed near his 100 Acre Wood. He returns and becomes a Van Helsing type character. I actually wanted to see this movie for an unique reason. The news reported that this was banned in Hong Kong due to Xi's disgust with the Winnie the Pooh comparison. Maybe they could do something with that since I hear they are planning a sequel.

review_title: If you go down to the woods today
review_detailed_main: It becomes time in every young boy and girls life when they must grow up. Though sometimes it's not always for the best. As poor Christopher robin realizes after returning with girlfriend Anne to the 100 aches woods after abandoning his friends there. But pooh and piglet are not the cuddly critters they once were, now they are feral with the taste of human flesh. As a group of very hot woman are about to find out after going on a little trip to get some much needed r and r. It's not long before the unfriendly animals are out for blood. It's pretty brutal but the blood is good. The acting is cheesy and I don't mind that. Overall blood and honey is a silly film in ways but it's nice seeing the story take a horror turn.

If they removed all of the actors except for the kill scenes, this would be a pretty decent movie, which is why I gave it a 5. Not one of the actors was good besides the guys in the suits. All of the girls characters were written so you would hate them and want Pooh to take them apart. The one primary male character whined the whole time. I should have counted how many times he whined "sorry" and "Pooh" and "why". That basically sums up his full set of lines.

This is really just "almost" a decent horror movie, but the horrible human characters is what really killed it. I have not read other reviews, so I can give nothing but what I seen in the movie.

When i heard they were making a 'horror' film out of Winnie the Pooh i laughed, but was somewhat intrigued by the concept. I could actually see it working...IF it was done right.

So, this film was released and it's not been done right. I don't quite understand why they've made Winnie look so obviously rubber. He's a bear, there should be fur on him. I honestly think having a 'cutesy' looking yellow furry bear as an antagonist would have more of an effect. Piglet too, just looks ridiculous. Imagine the horror of seeing characters which at least resemble the original characters running amok with hammers and axes? It would be an amazing juxtaposition to see on screen.

All that aside, the acting in this just isn't very good. It's very clearly made made on the budget of a box of Quavers and can of 'Top Deck'. The lighting at times is absolutely terrible, the script is poor. Overall this is a disappointing film, which is a real shame, because i loved the idea of a slasher starring Winnie the Pooh.

We all knew what we were about to get, and it didn't exceed its expectations nor go above it. This was just an average B-class horror movie, and it succeeded in that. Better than Cocaine Bear in my opinion.

The story started off well, but I think they should have shown us more about the story's characters and developed them more. Because now, once they showed us what happened, the story development just ended.

Some of the kills were nicely gory, but somehow they were still lacking and felt too censored, as if someone was holding them back. Most of the characters were absolute morons, and there was no logic.

Overall, if you're looking for a mindless, bloody horror movie to watch with friends, this might be for you. However, if you're looking for something more substantial, you might want to look elsewhere. It's not a movie to be taken too seriously, but if you're willing to throw your brains out for a while, it can be a fun ride.

Just an average B-class horror movie. Definitely not worse than Cocaine Bear and this is somewherre between 4-5 stars.

review_title: As good as it is bad
review_detailed_main:
I watched this with subtitles and music, so I can't comment on voices or noises.

However I could tell that the script was bad, the acting was even worse and the plot was non existent. The masks which weren't supposed to be masks but actual heads looked totally like masks.

That out of the way. There was good here too. For starters, the individual murder scenes were spot on, even though expected, they were gruesome because they were slow and detailed and didn't hold back.

However the whole thing was held up nicely due to the outstanding cinematography. There were many scenes that I would happily have as a desktop background. I sometimes paused to appreciate a scene.

Even some of the drone shots were quite inventive.

I feel torn, between having been entertained and thinking a 6 year old could have written a better film and acted better.

Overall, I enjoyed it as the slasher and eye candy it was, and would have given it more, but can't due to the absolute train wreck it was at the same time.

review_title: This movie is an insult to the viewer's intelligence
Intriguing premise, but utterly predictable with idiotic characters.

review_detailed_main: I don't get why people are hating on it. It deserves better than this. It was a fun enjoyable movie especially if you want to see a horror movie of Winnie the Pooh and piglet as killers. Seeing a movie with a budget around 100K and making 2 million at the box office is really impressive for a low budget horror film I'm really happy with the way it turned out and I'm looking forward to seeing the sequel let's see what you got for us Winnie the Pooh blood and honey 2. Also The Music Score For Blood And Honey Did A Amazing Job And The Beginning Of The Movie The Drawing Animation Is Terrific And Well Done.

Movie was very entertaining and no way should it have this many 1 scores. Most of these bad reviews are just Disney schills and employees that are giving it a negative review ad campaign.

I'm excited to see where the sequel takes the franchise and it is definitely better than any Disney remake that they have put out. The House of Mouse must truly be upset that they didn't get to ruin Winnie the Poohs legacy themselves.

There is plenty of gore and and it's a solid slasher film. The acting and film quality is good for such a low budget. I would have loved to see what they could have done more with some more financing.

This is a terrible terrible movie. The characters look nothing like the characters from 100 Acres Woods.

The masks are terrible. Really really terrible. The opening has a voice over that they no longer talk after being abandoned by Christopher Robin. Clearly this is to cover up for the masks that do not allow their wearing to speak, let alone emote.

This could be any other random slasher where the killers wear masks and it would maybe be a bit better. But with the entire rationale of the killers revealed during the opening voice over, there is no opportunity for suspense. We know they are going to kill indiscriminately.

The characters murdered are entirely unlikable, doing typically horror movie victim tropes as they wander towards their inevitable death.

There is literally nothing here that makes this Winnie The Pooh other than cheap Halloween masks and a wooden sign that that says 100 Acre Woods. They didn't even try insulting the audiences' childhood memories.

This movie had a lot of potential but the director missed the opportunity. The story was same as a slasher survival thriller but the back story of Winnie The Pooh and Christopher Robin felt too weak. You are unable to connect with their emotions. The characters of Pooh and Piglet looked like some murderers dressed as Pooh and Piglet. Rest I know that it is made on a small budget of $99K due to which the director may also be restricted to some extent.

Overall, it was a below average slasher thriller which you can give a watch just for silly fun and expect nothing good from it. Just go for silly fun!

This is so bad that I just couldn't stop watching. The film could have been so much more. Yes, there's lots of blood and gore, but the story is just odd and the costumes of Pooh and Piglet are like a bad fancy dress. Couldn't stop watching once I'd started, but not in a good way... more because it was like a car crash.

I think this was an opportunity lost to make a cracking film which would have ruined Winnie the Pooh for countless adults that grew up with him. However, no doubt this will eventually become one of those classic films like 'Bad Taste'. I wonder if they'll make a sequel and spit roast Piglet!?!?!?

As someone who grew up with Winnie the Pooh, and didn't like it at all, I loved this only because it made me laugh. Almost until I cried.

Story wise, it was not well written. It could have been better. There are some characters missing in my opinion. There was a weird phasing in the movie, and not enough moments that could draw your attention to what was happening. Sure I laughed, but was then bored most of the time.

The music could have been better too. And use of ambiance, and 'nail biting' moments where missing. But otherwise it was a funny movie to watch. And highly appreciated in that way.

review_title: Not as Bad as People Make Out
review_detailed_main: Honestly, it's not all that bad. Some of the shots in it are actually quite well done. The writing and acting are no worse that many other low budget slashers movies. Despite some really dodgy special effects, there are a few really effective ones in there too. The real disappointment is how generic it all is. Take away the masks from Pooh and Piglet and it could be any run-of-the-mill low budget slasher. It's just so unimaginative for something that could have been really different. Still, with an inevitable sequel on the way given how profitable it was, maybe the second one will take more risks and bring something interesting to the table.

Great premise for a film. There isn't the best acting, scripting, or effects. But it does get quickly into the thick of it and keeps the momentum up fairly well. There are definitely a few things I think they should have done differently, but the atmosphere and characters they built up in Pooh and Piglet were a win.

People expecting the glitz and glam of a high budget and a world class director may be put off. But if you're into a horror that you can take with a pinch of salt, it's pretty entertaining in all.

I'm glad that I didn't listen to all the negative reviews for the film and decided to give this a go.

review_title: Blood and Honey made loads of money.
review_detailed_main:
A group of young women spending time in a house near 100 Acre Wood are attacked by Winnie the Pooh and Piglet, who have gone feral after being abandoned by Christopher Robin.

Winnie The Pooh: Blood and Honey has received a great deal of coverage solely for the fact that it subverts children's favourite Winnie The Pooh, turning the once cuddly bear into a brutal killer-this made possible after the character fell into the public domain.

So what does the film offer besides its novel premise? Well, there's some reasonable gore, as Pooh and Piglet, wielding machete and sledgehammer, whittle down the victims, and there's some brief gratuitous nudity; however, I think that, given the ridiculous nature of the film, the level of blood and boobs could have been upped to make the film a far more trashy treat.

Unfortunately, the film also delivers wooden acting and terrible writing, with two-dimensional characters who act like morons, and plenty of inconsistencies and gaffs (is Hundred Acre Wood in the UK? If so, why does one character refer to petrol as 'gas'? And how does one of the girls have a gun?). Having introduced the human characters, the script goes nowhere, content to simply bump off the girls one by one, which soon becomes boring. Rhys Frake-Waterfield's direction is passable, but genuine scares are in very short supply.

It's a shame, because this film's version of Pooh is a fairly creepy creation, like Leatherface, but with a little black nose, wiggly ears and a taste for honey. Because of the media exposure the film received, the film has managed to turn a tidy profit (nearly $5m on a $100k budget), meaning the inevitable sequel is already in the works. Let's hope that a bit more attention is given to the script next time around, and that they dial up the trashiness, making the sequel the enjoyably over-the-top slice of excess that it deserves to be.

review_title: Not bad give it a go!!
review_detailed_main: For a amateur film this is not terrible I've seen a lot of amateur films and this one is one of the better ones for sure don't listen to negative reviews watch it yourself and see for yourself what you think definitely not bad! A lot of time and effort was put into this one you can tell! Now if you're a big fan of Winnie the Pooh in General and don't want to see a negative version of the characters this is definitely not for you! I recommend at least giving it a go I was pleasantly surprised and how much effort they put into not letting it look like one of those horrible cheap amateur films we're all use too!!

review_title: People don't realise that this Movie is supposed to be Bad
Not even a good bad movie
review_detailed_main:
I like a trashy movie on occasion. So bad it's good can definitely be entertaining. And I'm a fan of ridiculous slashers, as long as they can be silly/tongue-in-cheek. I'm sorry to say that this movie is far from that. It's mean, almost cruel sometimes. The kills are nothing special, the characters are easily forgettable and interchangeable, and the killers are bland.

The production value is surprisingly decent at times, but everything from script to acting lackluster. I even watched Jason X earlier in the day just because, and that dumpster fire of a movie is WAY more entertaining. If you want to see it for yourself, okay, but honestly, you can totally skip this one.

review_title: It's not that bad...... or good...
review_detailed_main:
It's a fairly run-of-the-mill, 6 women in the woods, horror film.

The weak parts are really in the tie in to Pooh.

The opening sequence is tough - the guy playing Christopher Robbin is simply a horrible, horrible, actor. But the sequence explains a bit.

The worst part of the entire film is the Pooh and Piglet makeup. It just looks like actors wearing bargain-basement, low-rent, silicon Halloween masks. At NO POINT is it believable that these are actual living version of Pooh and Piglet - just actors wearing really bad masks.

Other than the horrible masks and the terrible acting by "Christopher Robbin" it's just a standard woodland slasher story.

I'd give it a 4.5! The best moment was a BioShock Plasmid moment. Tons of potential for the sequel, but this entire film was just filled to the brim with cliché women doing the dumbest crap that only women could be seen doing in a real life situation like this lol and a very predictable plot. Winnie was actually pretty awesome and an absolute tank. Not gonna lie. Massive props on that aspect. The kills were C+ IMO. The cinematography was average; though some shaky cam moments got tedious very quickly. The characters dynamic felt forced. The soundtrack was actually solid. I'd say that it's worth a watch at least once. A tier or two above Jeepers Creepers 3 haha.

review_title: Christopher Robin, you have a lot to answer for.
review_detailed_main:
Imagine a world where the beloved Winnie The Pooh went bad, a world where he chased blood instead of honey......someone actually had that idea.

Where do you even begin with this one, let's be honest, if you've put it on, you're more than aware of what is about to follow, and if you're preconceived ideas are that it's a bad film, your instincts are right.

One of those films that is so cringe, that it's entertaining, and that whole twist of something beloved from childhood, something sweet and safe going rogue, I liked that.

So yes, it's low budget, and that shows, it's more than a little rough around the edges, but there were some interesting moments, and Winnie the Pooh......I've seen worse.

The acting is average at best, and some of the dialogue is abysmal, one line in particular, just shocking.

You were warned.

4/10.

Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey (2023) is a horror film directed by Rhys Frake-Waterfield and written by Waterfield and Mark Gooder. The film stars Rhys Frake-Waterfield, Jack Holden, and Suzanne Maddock. The film follows Pooh and Piglet as they become feral and bloodthirsty after Christopher Robin leaves them.

The film was released in the United Kingdom on February 15, 2023, and in the United States on August 25, 2023. It received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising its originality and others criticizing its poor acting and direction.

The film's plot is simple but effective. Pooh and Piglet become feral and bloodthirsty after Christopher Robin leaves them. They then go on a rampage, killing anyone who gets in their way. The film is well-paced and suspenseful, and the kills are gory and satisfying.

The performances are mixed. Frake-Waterfield and Holden are both adequate as Pooh and Piglet, but they lack the charisma and charm of the original characters. Maddock is the best of the bunch as Christopher Robin, but she is not given much to do.

The direction is uneven. Frake-Waterfield does a good job of creating a sense of tension and suspense, but he also makes some poor choices, such as using shaky cam and quick cuts.

The visual effects are decent. The gore is realistic and the kills are well-executed. However, the CGI is not always convincing, especially when it comes to the animals.

Overall, Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey is a mixed bag. It has some good qualities, such as its originality and its gore, but it also has some poor qualities, such as its acting and its direction. If you are a fan of horror films, then you may enjoy this film. However, if you are looking for a well-made and faithful adaptation of Winnie the Pooh, then you will be disappointed.

The film's box office success is likely due to its novelty. People were intrigued by the idea of a horror film based on Winnie the Pooh, and they were not disappointed. The film made over $10 million at the box office, which is considered a success for a low-budget horror film.

Overall, I would give Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey a 5 out of 10. It has some good qualities, such as its originality and its gore, but it also has some poor qualities, such as its acting and its direction. If you are a fan of horror films, then you may enjoy this film. However, if you are looking for a well-made and faithful adaptation of Winnie the Pooh, then you will be disappointed.

review_title: The art, photography and directing was 10/10
review_detailed_main:
Yes the development of the story sucked a lot, the premise was good but it was badly executed. The acting was lacking too as well as the special effects.

However I stopped paying attention to it when I realized how beautifuly made the art, photography and directing was.

I also believe that the whole movie was mostly made at one place; the woods, so that was a very smart decision on production.

So yeah if you're looking to rate this movie on it's story it won't even get two stars. But I believe every frame was art and although it won't make a good movie for everyone I must say I was extremely impressed by everyone involved on the visuals.

review_title: Winnie the pooh blood and honey

review_detailed_main: Well I will say this is o e crazy crazy film. The overall concept is crazy. The actual movie it's self is crazy. So this is a dark and gritty film so if you are expecting to see some cute adult version of Winnie the Pooh, well you will get a adult version but it will not be pretty. This film is gritty. Winnie the Pooh and Piglet are upset that Christopher went away to college so they completely flip out and go on a brutal, and I mean brutal, killing spree. They kill several and attempt to kill several others. I wouldn't say the film is a waste like other viewers did it's just very gritty. Ok horror film to view once.

review_title: This will be the flag movie in the bottom of all my rankings.
review_detailed_main:
I just watched the worst movie since I saw The Son of the Mask. It's incredible that in every aspect that a feature film can have there are clear and marked deficiencies.

Blood and Honey is a bad, poorly made film, one of those that becomes irritating to watch, because even the least expert audience in anything related to cinema notices the many errors that this film has in editing, direction, photography, etc. The script is so bad that the dialogues have no reason to exist. They are repetitive, unnecessary, redundant, meaningless. The plot is so bad that it's not even unintentionally funny. The masks, which really shouldn't look like masks, are also horrible. In short, it's a long list of bad aspects, bad sensations, bad executions that encompass a disastrous film from every angle you look at it.

I recommend it only for those who like movies that are so bad that they are good, although this one is not even mediocre.

It goes right to the bottom of all my rankings.

review_title: You Left... Me Mad After Watching This
review_detailed_main:
Jesus, where to begin. I think I'll start by saying this: was this movie even necessary? Did we really need this? I think we didn't, but we did.

This movie is just the definition of low budget. The lighting is terrible, there are pointless scenes, and the acting is somewhat uneven. Honestly though, the worst part is they don't even try to hide the fact that Pooh and Piglet were guys in masks. THE MASKS WEREN'T EVEN MADE FOR THE FILM THEY WERE PURCHASED.

Ok, I got it out of my system. There are some good things, like it's kills and locations, but that may be about it. Oh yeah, the musical score was something I enjoyed, at least that got some effort.

Bottom line, this movie is simply clickbait horror. I wouldn't blame you if you watch it, but lower expectations.

review_title: Not Good But Not THAT bad
review_detailed_main: This movie wastes an interesting premise and reduces the classic denizens of the 100-Acre Wood to lumbering slashers. It's bloody, it's brutal, it's cheap and it's completely idiotic. It is not, however, as bad as critical reviews indicate. A 4% on RT and op-eds calling this one of the 100 worst movies ever made is critical hyperbole. It's certainly not good, of course, but there's dumb fun to be had with the concept and the over-the-top brutality if you're in the right mindset; especially if you're with a group that's prepared to laugh at the inanity. It's not completely incompetent or without merit. In fact, considering its reported budget of just $100k it's pretty slick and polished and some of the effects (rubber bear and swine masks aside) are impressive.

review_title: Still not sure what we expect
review_detailed_main:
When hearing the announcement with a concept such as Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey announced it's safe to say you can toss out any pre-conceived notions that this is going to become an instant classic of modern cinema that will forever have it's long lasting impression made and be studied in film schools for decades to come. Instead, it's better to theorize that this is going to be something that allows itself to have fun and come in and out of your live on a boring Monday night, never to be forgotten but with little memory to live on.

Having watched this movie now I have a difficult time placing it. As silly as it is and as much fun as it wants to have, and it does have its fun, believe it or not this movie still manages to take itself a little too seriously for its own goods. They were never going to pull off genuine scares or worthwhile storytelling in this one so why even try? The best moments of the movie are when it lets itself go and have some fun, which is exactly what it should be doing, but its weaknesses come in when it wants to be a real horror movie. That just doesn't work with something like this unless there are some truly gifted minds behind it.

I don't give it a 3 because I had my expectations set high for something incredible. I give it a 3 because it failed to deliver on the fun it promised just by existing.

review_title: I liked the narration in the beginning; nothing else!
review_detailed_main: I enjoyed a lot old-school style narration by Tobe Wynn-Davies in the very beginning over black and white animation, portraying how Winnie-the-Pooh and Piglet became vicious psychotic sadistic murderers. It was nice. Unfortunately, nothing else was not only nice but even mediocre (acting, perhaps, was uninspired but acceptable). Except for Eeyore, they never explained why the others, Owl and Rabbit, did not appear in live action fraction (possibly just for budgetary reasons; Tigger, Kanga and Roo are not even mentioned). The human guys with bear and pig masks were tremendously ridiculous. I simply cannot believe that even a B-film producer from Great Britain does not have enough money for at least rent adult full costumes for presenting properly Pooh and Piglet. Considering the exploitation I just watched, the guy, Rhys Frake-Waterfield, also seem to be a mysoginist (I do not want to imagine what he may have done to Wendy and Tinkerbell in his horror spoof of Peter Pan). The great amount of clichés you may find in this Z-movie have already been assembled in a much better way in several formulaic mainstream films before. It was amazing how every single character stopped to see the others being beaten and killed, instead of running the faster they could (very few times someone tried to help; therefore, it was just just that same morbid curiousity that makes drivers stop the car or drive slower when they see victims after traffic accidents). To resume, what is the moral of the story, after all? I guess it is a warning about the importance of learning how to swim. You may need that skill if an anthropomorphic pig attacks you with a maul in a swimming pool. You never know...

Intro was fine then it just sucked. It was in a fun way until it became so repetitive and boring that I almost wished that Winnie visited me instead.

Acting is poor and it shows. Then again I guess it would be hard to display any acting skills with a script as broken as this ones is. The intro was pretty good and I think that's the only part of the movie the crew had any idea what to do with. I feel like the rest of movie was just made up as they went.

The camera work is pretty good and there is some really nice gore effects. CGI is at its minimum and it's replaced with some awful looking costumes.

All in all without spoiling anything this is truly one of those movies that will have you question your life choices after watching.

review_title: for all its faults i'm still glad it exists.
review_detailed_main:
For starters, this comes as no surprise that something like this finally emerged, and i'm sure is just the beginning of what i'm assuming is a tidal wave of similar projects in development.

There was a lot of potential here, but the acting and script writing took dives a lot throughout the film as well some continuity inconsistencies and other elements that left one scratching one's head.... Maybe those questions will be answered in the (hopefully better produced) sequel.

Overall it does what its supposed to: a middle finger towards certain powers that be as the period of Pooh this movie draws upon is now in the public domain, and a lot of fairly well articulated gore.

I will definitely watch the sequel if it gets made.

When I watched this movie I eventually in with no expectations. I was pleasantly surprised. Blood and Honey is not a good movie. It's poorly written, there are some directorial shots that would never make a movie made by a studio, and there is some pretty cringe acting as well. The characters are paper-thin to the point I can't remember any names. The pacing is a bit off and the effects at times were notably bad.

But what did you expect on a budget under $100,000 made by amateurs? I don't feel like my time was wasted by people who used an IP as a lazy money grab. I thought the team tried and did what they could within their means.

There were a handful of cool directorial shots, a few fun kills, and some bad in an entertaining way scenes that made this at least watchable. It's a really short film that isn't an absolute chore to get through. This isn't even the worst horror film I've seen this year, plus there where naked boobies which always raises the rating.

There are some cases of movies in which just by seeing the poster you have a good glimpse of what you are going to watch. There's no point in me doing a synopsis, because if for some sick reason you've ever dreamed of a movie where Winnie the Pooh (yes, the bear from your childhood) goes psychotic and on a killing spree, that's just what you're going to get in this movie.

I want to clarify something, being objective this is not a good movie even remotely. As far as slashers are concerned, it is quite mediocre, although it has some brutal deaths at the end, it is overshadowed by films such as Terrifier.

So why do I give it a 10? Because the plot, although it is quite stupid, is very funny at the same time, seeing the fat bear torture and kill its victims. It's something worth seeing, even if it's just out of curiosity. The funniest thing is that the movie itself is not a comedy, it might seem like it takes itself seriously and that makes it all the more fun. Also, I must say that Piglet's squeals give the film a plus.

In short, the best way to watch this movie is to understand that it's one of those so bad it's good movies, and not take it seriously at all. If you don't find the idea of Winnie the Pooh killing people at least a bit fun, you should do well by skipping this one.

I was having a bad weekend. And I wanted a punching bag to reduce my frustration. This is a kind of movie that I watch in such situations. It definitely eased my pain. Now you know why I rate it so high.

I like it when a director doesn't follow the herd and make a movie the way he wants. Winnie the Pooh is one man's fantasy work. It delivered exactly what I expected from it.

It never felt boring. It has perfect length, just below one and a half hour. The casting was perfect. Beautiful British girls. Sweet. Many recent movies failed in this aspect. I'm a fan of 80s slashers. Those movies succeeded because of small things I mentioned above. This movie gave similar vibes to me. The director know his target audience. Unfortunately majority of the viewers disliked it, but I know there are few fun people out there who enjoyed it.

Some critics called it misogynistic and gory, and gave it 1/5. Well, yes, it was gory. Misogynistic? Hell no. You guys need to do better to discredit this movie. I mean, I noted that point when I was reading a review and I specifically looked for it while watching. I did not see it at all. Men and women were equally treated here. The people who said that it has ruined their childhood and was unnecessary, you adult-babies are soft as sponge. You know you are allowed to not watch this if you feel uncomfortable. I didn't watch the live action of Scooby-Doo for similar reason. Some people are living inside a rigid moral fence. Come out of it. It is a "horror" movie. Dark comedy is a thing.

2023 wasn't a great year for horror. This movie saved it from becoming one of the worst years for horror fans. I'm happy there are directors who utilise the opportunities like these.

review_title: It was as to be expected...
review_detailed_main:
When I first saw the poster for this movie, I figured that it was a fun thing to make a movie about. However, I have to say that I wasn't harboring much of any high hopes or expectations to the movie, because it just seemed to have things stacked against it.

But as I had the opportunity to watch the movie, of course I did. And yeah, "Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey" from writer and director Rhys Frake-Waterfield is every bit as you would expect it to be. So don't hold your breath here hoping for a great movie.

The storyline in the movie was shallow, if not actually downright laughably stupid. Sure, in concept the idea of the creatures of the 100 Acre Forest growing full of hate and resentment after being abandoned when Christopher grew up actually seems like a fun idea and an interesting enough concept. However, the transition from script to movie just didn't make for an overly entertaining movie.

The acting performances in the movie were actually fair enough. Sure, the actors and actresses didn't really have much of anything to work with, but they managed to put on good enough performances nonetheless.

What does work for the movie are some of the kill scenes. I have to say, as a lifelong gorehound, then some of the slayings in the movie were actually interesting to watch and executed, pardon the pun, nicely on the screen. But that was essentially also all that "Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey" had going for it.

Visually then "Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey" was a bag of mixed nuts. Piglet and Pooh looked awful, especially with those inarticulate latex masks the actors were wearing. It was just so difficult to take them serious and buy into them being the once-beloved Piglet and Pooh characters. Some of the gore and mayhem during the killing scenes were quite good though.

"Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey" is not a movie that impressed me, and it actually was everything I had initially feared.
