And while I did manage to sit through the 84 minutes, then I can honestly say that I am never returning to it a second time. Nor is it a movie that I would recommend you waste your time, money or effort on.

I will say that "Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey" is actually a droning, monotonous experience of a movie, because the narrative settles into a gearless slump and never goes up or down, the characters in the movie were generic and made some very stupid decisions and actions. And there weren't any thrills or excitement to be found throughout the 84 minutes of monotonous storytelling.

My rating of "Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey" lands on a three out of ten stars.

4/10. So now someone made a micro budget horror movie based on an interesting premise. For 2023, beloved children's character Winnie the Pooh turns into a blood-thirsty, murderous creature. Also, Piglet is on this insane, low budget ride. Please keep in mind that this film was made under 100K.

It is a good, well made movie? Nope, it is not. Is it a so bad that its good movie? Meh, not really; only time will tell. It's a fun, twisted idea to turn beloved family characters into angry, gore hound villains though. Some of the kills are ok but were really held back due to the small budget. This film did have a couple of jump scares and some gory scenes. I'm trying to not judge this too harshly considering. Surprisingly, the music and cinematography were quite well done. The "masks" for the creature are quite goofy and comedic.

Biggest problem was that it is way too dark in much of the movie. Literally, there are a couple of scenes that are hard to tell what's going on. The characters you just don't care about, there are some awkward cuts, some of the character's decisions don't make any sense, the plot is quite dumb, and that low budget 80's horror charm wasn't there. I hope that for the sequel and their expanded horror universe; they get a bigger budget and better script polishing.

I support this type of film making and only hope it gets better on for the filmmakers. Honesty, my expectations were quite low and I just wanted to have fun watching it. It was kind of fun but felt like they should have had more fun and humor in it. Just set your expectations low and don't think too much about it.

This film was made possible by the expiration of the Winnie The Pooh copyright, which moved the characters into the Public Domain.

Effectively making something like this an inevitability.

As John Oliver has pointed out on his weekly HBO show, this is precisely what Disney fears will happen to their beloved Mickey Mouse, when their time is eventually up.

Which is why they are incessantly lobbying and scheming to keep their dear little mouse under the protection of the much loathed federal copyright act.

Because this is hilarious.

It was never meant to be good.

So if you were going into thinking it was going to be...that is totally a you problem.

As, for what it is...it's actually not that bad.

Sure...there is some lazy use of CGI for bloodspatter.

But the film does employ a healthy amount of practical effects, as well.

And there are some pretty cool kills.

Sure, the premise suggested in the announce of the film, isn't inherently obvious (ie that Pooh and Piglet are seeking out a new source of food).

But the basic premise, otherwise, works as much as it needs to.

That being that Pooh and Piglet have snapped, after being ditched by Christopher Robin, after he left them to go off to college.

The plotline- that they are looking for food- is only used to suggest the murder and consumption of Eyeore, in the intro.

Short of that, the rest of the film just seems to be the wanton- and baseless- killing of random individuals (who just so happened to enter their forest)...without any noticeable attempt to actually eat them.

But it is what it is.

And it's certainly not as bad as most reviewers will have you think.

I mean.

Of course it's bad.

But it's meant to be bad.

So you have to engage with it on that front.

Not going in expecting some sort of masterpiece, or something.

Because for such a low budget feature.

It's actually pretty darn entertaining!

And rather well done.

That is, If you don't mind a little bit of torture, and some mindless, senseless killing...doled out by characters that were likely formative parts of your childhood experience.

Even if tying them to those characters requires a slight stretch of the imagination.

Because they bear no particular resemblance to the iconic illustrations you know and love, at all.

Though, with that being said...based on everything people were saying about it...I honestly expected it to be far worse than it actually is.

So colour me pleasantly surprised.

If you hated this...just wait for the sequel.

It's sure to ruin you.

Because you know it's coming.

3 out of 10.

This movie wasn't as bad as I was expecting, but there was so much that could have been done better.

The gratuitous female nudity is a trope that's been done to death and adds exactly zero to the plot. It was unnecessary and not particularly alluring. To be honest, there aren't any enticing, sexy male or female characters as is par for the course in cheap horror, so if that's what you're looking for, you'll find yourself disappointed.

The acting wasn't great, but it's tolerable and better than expected from a "cheesy" B grade horror with a very small budget.

The concept of a demonic Pooh bear is fun, but the movie doesn't really go anywhere else. The kills are excessive, which is what you want in a film like this. If you're squeamish, be prepared going in.

Overall, this movie wasn't as interesting or as suspenseful as it could've been, even with a weak plot. There isn't much buildup so it there just isn't enough time for the movie to be scary or creepy. If you're looking for a B grade slasher flick with gore porn and tolerable-ish acting/characters, you may enjoy this.

review_title: Um, that's a really BAD movie
review_detailed_main: First of all, when I first watched the trailer of the movie, I had mixed feelings about it. Because, when I was younger I loved Winnie the Pooh, but I decided to watch that movie... Eventually, I shouldn't have watched that movie, because it was terrible! The plot of the movie wasn't very interesting and it was really silly. The storyline was terribly written and very childish. The characters weren't very interesting, nor well-developed and not really likeable. The filming location of the movie was just a house in the middle of the woods, nothing new. The casting of the movie was just some amateur actors and actresses and their acting wasn't really good... The killcount of the movie was really bloody and gory, but most kills weren't realistic at all. The opening scene of the movie was ULTRA CRINGE and I didn't really enjoyed it. The ending scene was kinda unexpected, but it was so silly and I didn't really care what was gonna happen, lol. Overall, it was a low budget horror movie that had a terrible concept and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. Last but not least, I'm still kinda shocked that there's gonna be a sequel, literally WTF.

First off, I love the whole idea of taking a children's program and turning it to horror. Second, I was thrilled with the blood and guts that was displayed and CANNOT wait until the sequel comes out. The special effects in the death scenes were TOP NOTCH. You don't typically get to see the character essentially take their last breath on camera. The actor playing Christopher Robin could have done a little better, but it wasn't enough for me to rate this any less than a 10. I have been looking forward to this movie since I heard it was coming out and I was NOT disappointed. Instantly one of my favorites!!!!

The storyline of the movie was rather underwhelming and lacked the depth required to engage the audience. Furthermore, the movie had some rather unusual twists and turns that may have detracted from the overall viewing experience. Additionally, the introduction to the film was rather abrupt and felt rushed, not allowing the audience enough time to fully comprehend the setting or characters.

However, the film was visually striking and left a lasting impression on the audience. The imagery was breathtaking, with stunning silhouettes and excellent use of light and shadow. The composition of the shots was also outstanding, adding an extra layer of intrigue to the film. The camera work was masterfully executed, successfully balancing the suspenseful elements of the movie with captivating still shots that highlighted the excellent composition and views.

Overall, while the story may have been lacking, the visual elements of the film were a true work of art and a testament to the skill and artistry of the filmmakers.

Not a movie I would recommend others to watch. Bad and illogical acting. The storyline makes no sense and the "costume" for Winnie the Pooh and Piglet are ugly and don't look professional. And where are the other characters? They could have made it better and more interesting to watch. The ending is also bad and you don't understand what is going to happen. It seems to be a part 2 of the movie, so it will be interesting to see how bad it will be. My advise is: Don't waste your time. You can find other more interesting and professional movies to watch than this movie. It is really not worth watching.

I love Winnie the pooh, I've watched it since i was a child. Growing into my teen years, i started to like horror movies, once i saw this came out i went and watched it. This is by far the worst horror movie I've watched. It had to have been poorly made or something because I've seen 90's to the early 2000's have way better horror movies than this. The way i never got the thrill of watching it. The thrill you usually would get loving horror movies. The chase scenes weren't good. Its way better when the killer creepily walks while you run luring you somewhere you can't escape out of but instead the killer just full on sprinted towards the victim. There is way more, but I don't need to write a whole essay about how bad it is when it's obvious.

This is quite possibly one of the worst movie ever made, not just of 2020 decade, but of all time. I mean, how could someone green-light this hot trash? They really ruined Winnie the Pooh just to bring someones weird horror film flick to life. This films just shouldn't exist, this films like on of those fake trailers online. The story is garbage, the designs are terrible, the acting is horrendous, and everything else is just horrible. Just save your self from this & don't watch it, go watch something that won't waste your time Again easily one of the worst films I've ever seen in my whole life.

review_title: The film could be so much better.
review_detailed_main:
The concept of the film is really interesting. I really like Pooh and Piglet's costume design, those will be really good for Halloween. However, the storyline could be much much better. It could be one of those too bad to be good kind of epic movies like Flash Golden or Shaknado but I am bit disappointed as it waste it's potential. I agree with most of review here that they should have focus on Christopher Robin or make it as dark humour. The character development of those ladies are not great, the acting is bad and underwhelming, I know they are disposable characters but still you want to see some sort of personality of those characters, but no, no such thing. The ending is pretty unique, but it makes me feel so incomplete even for cliff hanger.

I give this film 3 star. 2 for the costume, 1 for the potential of the concept.

review_title: Lovers of Winnie the Pooh, no worries here
review_detailed_main: Was not as terrible as i thought i mean it was bad but not terrible. I worried they had ruined Pooh. They didn't. It was nothing like the beloved Pooh we grew up on. I grew up on Pooh, but i also grew up on Rated R. I was daddy's girl so could watch anything i wanted and i did. These are humanoid things not stuffed animals. Obviously Pooh we grew up on was stuffed animals. That Eeyore you couldn't eat as he was made of sawdust. So this C. Robin finds these animals, befriends them leaves them etc. I did like the old truck that was in the woods. Ties with good slashers; woods where people disappear so let's go stay at a cabin in those woods. Don't care for cartoony work at the beginning. These humanoids hateful things are killing people esp women. No interesting kills here. They've been throwing people in wood chippers for years. No sex scenes, sadly, and no gorgeous killer in a mask. I will say this for a big guy, Pooh could move. He was a hauling it thru those woods. Movie is like Halloween 3, the one that had nothing to do with Michael Myers. This had nothing to do with the Pooh we love and know. Kind of liked it. Hope they do another. How about a rabid Scooby Doo. Hope he does Bambi as promised now that one will be good, been dealing with deer poaching on my land for years. Deer do need to take up arms. Anyway, i hate women so obviously i'd hate the women in this, but not a terrible film.

review_title: Winnie the pooh to dark for you
review_detailed_main:
The start of the movie is easily the highlight, they could of made a 10-15min short film and absolutely blown it out of the park, but they went a different, more muddled, poorly written and edited path.. Other highlights include discount English Lindsay Lohan getting the always great and realistic mid-fight disrobing and fed into a woodchipper, and the girl with the Cumbrellas run in with Pooh's car...

The one thing all the characters had in common was the lack of will to survive... literally none of them put up any fight and basically just laid down and died...

Other than that it was filmed way to dark to be able to see half of what was going on, no real story or cohesion, but some pretty good kills sprinkled throughout the movie.

Costumes were quite cool, Pooh's was better than Piglet's but still both looked good.

I loved this horror version of Winnie the Pooh, to be honest. I actually did have very low expectations of this film. I was not expecting it to be good. I grew up watching Winnie the Pooh. I was shocked that someone turned it into a horror film. I heard there is going to be a sequel, I can not wait to watch it. I enjoyed this film and to see how they became murderous. Once this comes out on DVD, I will be buying it. The gore was good. I had to look away at some parts. I did get a Michael Myers vibe off a couple scenes lol. I can not believe I have to write a review that is six hundred characters.

Firstly, I think it's best to keep in mind this movie was made for around 70k, which is a fraction of the budget of bigger productions from the likes of Blumhouse - and to be honest, I enjoyed this a lot more than most of the stuff they churn out!

Second thing to remember is I don't think the guys behind this planned on it being the phenomenon it's turned out to be. Sure, there's flaws. The acting isn't the best (obviously because of the miniscule budget) and there's some CGI blood - but there is also a fair amount of practical too, which is always a big plus.

I genuinely did think this was a fairly decent little horror flick, and I'll definitely be interested to see what they do with the sequel as I've heard it's got a much bigger budget (around 250K apparently!)

review_title: So bad it's good? Sadly not...
review_detailed_main:
Well... this is a novel idea! Take a bunch of beloved kids characters and turn them into slasher villains! Bring it on!

Blood & Honey follows Christopher Robin, as he returns to his childhood home. Growing up with Pooh, Piglet and Eeyore, he eventually left to go to university, and now years later has returned to introduce his girlffiend to his childhood friends. Thing is, the gang were not able to fend for themselves, and ended up eating Eeyore just to stay alive. Growing to resent Christopher for leaving them and having to kill their friend to survive, Pooh and Piglet are now somewhat unhinged and very, very murderous...

This film was utterly decimated by critics upon release, but I wasn't put off as cheap shlocky horror movies never go down well with critics. I was completely on board with this concept and more than a little curious so I decided to check it out.

I really wanted to like this film, but boy does it make that difficult. I actually laughed out loud at how absolutely AWFUL the dialogue is. If you ever watch it, just listen to the lines Chris Robin's girlfriend says at the beginning! Who even talks like that!!!!? And it's not just her, nobody in this film talks like a real person. Yes, this film isn't the only one that suffers from bad dialogue, but DAMN... it's really jarring...

That aside, the film seems to be going for your typical Texas Chainsaw vibes... and Pooh and Piglet are so typecast as psychotic hillbillies that they could easily just be generic humans and it wouldn't matter. The fact that they are humanoid pigs and bears doesn't really serve much purpose in the film itself beyond the initial set up. They just look like humans wearing masks (which with a budget this low is probably exactly what they are).

Some pretty grim kills aside, this film doesn't really do anything that a billion other slasher movies haven't already done much better. The characters are all unlikable and have zero depth, the location is cliche and everyone is either dumb, annoying or both - including the killers. Amazingly, this film somehow got a sequel that is allegedly much better. Well... it can't be much worse...

review_title: THIS IS NOT FOR KIDS and is messed up
review_detailed_main: The critical consensus is just "Oh, bother", Pooh's famous catchphrase, and that should give an idea as to how bad the movie is - as per the critics at least. But even the audiences have given it a 58 per cent rating. Blood and Honey became possible because the copyright for the original stories and related illustrations by EH Shepard entered the public domain in the United States in 2021, 95 years after their first publication. This means that anyone is free to use the characters and stories in their own works without obtaining permission from the copyright holder. And writer-director Rhys Frake-Waterfield chose the moment to make a movie about Pooh and other inhabitants of Hundred Acre Wood psychopathic murders. The movie was said to be a retelling of the stories. In this adaptation, it's revealed that Christopher Robin and his animal friends did have all those adventures during Robin's childhood, but as he grew up and went to college, the animals became increasingly hungry and feral. Eventually, they became so deranged that they terrorise a group of girls who are staying in a rural cabin. It's even getting a sequel, but the initial reactions to this horror movie, which we've cobbled together below, have been less than kind with a Rotten Tomatoes score of 9% at the time of writing. Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey wastes an immediate-draw title on an underbaked, low-budget horror blunder that's rougher than sandpaper. Outside of a few good kills, even horror fans just looking for mindless slaughter will probably be frustrated by Rhys Frake-Waterfield's unimpressive and unamusing adaptation. Every choice becomes more baffling than the last, as if attention was only paid to how much gore slathers the screen rather than, for example, making the title character look better than something you might pull off the shelf at a Spirit Halloween shop in early November. Not every horror film needs an airtight approach and Oscar-worthy composition, but it's a crushing disappointment after Blood and Honey's delightfully twisted elevator pitch grabbed so much attention that it seems to struggle to succeed at even the most basic movie-making elements. "Oh bother?" Try "Why bother."

Just for comparison. I cannot understand how come people rate 4.7 a painfully awful ultra low-budget flick like "Book of Monsters" (2018), but only give 2.9 to this one, another ultra low-budget British flick but with some nicer and more interesting production values than the former. And more competently crafted overall.

I expected "Blood & Honey" to be an appalling visual experience because of the bad reviews here but in the end I actually kind of liked it. I am actually glad with my purchase of the Italian steelbook edition.

For me, the movie doesn't seem so ultra low-budget - kind of college-kids material like "Book of Monsters". And to be honest, even my girlfriend thought that the bunch of girls acted in a more realistic manner than young women in any other modern horror movie.

Like, these days all we get to see is skinny 50 kg & 1.60-metre tall gals successfully fending off and plucking up in Street Fighter fashion all those 110 kg & 1.90-metre tall male monster villains... As if throwing a kick to a male figure that size wouldn't most probably result in a fracture of their shin.

Most regular people over Britannia do not take kung Fu lessons or happen to be so determined, bold, cool-headed and supernaturally strong as say... Selene in Underworld. To take but an example.

All in all a B or Z movie I would most probably revist again in the future over some pizza and a beer.

review_title: It's so bad that it IS good
review_detailed_main: I'm seeing a lot of complaints that movie is just "bad," but if you didn't notice that the director leaned in on this on purpose, you're just stupid. It is all around a fun and goofy movie to watch. This movie had a budget that was less than $100,000, and it seems like that just gets thrown out the window when reviewing this movie. I went into the movie just looking for a good time, and that's what I got when I opened my mind to it. I think the main issue here is elderly people. If you're in the above 50 crowd, you're not going to like the movie. I cannot wait until the second movie, and everyone rating it bad is wrong. Ratio+L+Bozo take.

Very jarring but too ridiculous to not fond entertaining, this movie gives off similar vibes to terrifier but much worse, closer to the human centipede. Ironically enough in saying that, the cinematography itself isn't bad for majority of the film.

Now I do feel like this movie could've invested more time, effort and money in to honing the gore and making it more extreme, cataclysmic and vicious. The script also was very generic and could have been more satirical. Another problem I faced with the film was that, the entire time, I couldn't tell if the directors knew JUST how bad of a film they made or not, but I guess that just made it even funnier in my opinion.

For the people who hayed this film, I have questions.. 1. Did Christopher Robin and Winnie play a large part in your wonderful childhood?

2. Are you historically a fan of horror films?

3. If you hated the music, was it the rap music scenes or the orchestra jump scare?

4. Did you notice any relationship connection between the women or just the lesbians?

I have other questions but I will pin it there.

I am not historically a fan of horror, mostly due to the obvious ...the killing and blood, the times when women run and fall right in front of the murderer, the intense music that makes you know someone is going to get it; it is all so heart pounding. But, my daughter loves old horror films and I take her when I know it will be the fakest scenarios ever. That way I'm not afraid at bedtime. Did I hide my eyes from time to time, yes. I also found that I laughed out loud at the ridiculousness of some of the scenes? Who responds that way to a nearby threat?? That type of action and those types of responses made me remember that this IS JUST ENTERTAINMENT!!!

I liked this film. Will I ever rent an Air BnB in the middle of nowhere??? Heeeck no! But I will watch this again...in the daytime and in the city.

Christopher was always the least interesting character in the 100 acre wood. That he should not play a major role is a plus. That they've re-imagined the lead characters is also a plus. But the dialogue is mediocre and the acting sub-par. The entire concept is a gimmick. But so what? It's a horror film. It's fun, not philosophical. Their choice of characters, however, seems rushed and unoriginal, as if they hurried to be the first out of the gate once public domain took effect. Can't fault them for that, but hopefully the sequel will improve on that. If not, there will be others. Now that the stranglehold has been released, who knows where it will go?

The fact that any giant conglomerate can claim ownership to other people's creative works, after stealing them and irreparably changing the very nature of them, only proves that they deserve to have their name buried in obscurity. And by obscurity, I mean the cesspool of all the putrid bowdlerizations ever thrust upon the unsuspecting childhood of every unfortunate being unlucky enough to have been exposed to its toxic banality.

So, if creative works can't be protected from the unscrupulous moneybags of unoriginal saccharine filth. More power to the independent purveyors of somewhat less unoriginal filth. There's more creativity in a simple brush stroke of a small group of film makers than in any giant corporation with all their algorithms, marketing research and influence on artificially deflated rating systems. How does a 6.6 become a 3.4? Bags of money.

OK; I know a lot of people didn't like this movie, but I thought it was pretty good. The only thing that threw me off was the masks. Anyway, I like how Rhys Frake-Waterfield & Scott Chambers turned Pooh & Piglet into horror versions of themselves to get revenge on Christopher Robin for abandoning them. It was sad that they had to eat Eeyore. I thought Maria & her friends would survive against Pooh & Piglet, but boy was I wrong. I watched the sequel, but you'll have to wait to see my thoughts on that movie. Now, how would I rate this movie? I guess I'll rate it a 7/10. Also, to those who don't like this film I respect your opinion.

review_title: Instant classic for those of us who know how to have fun
review_detailed_main: Great kills and some great cinematography. Enjoy it for what it is and don't listen to the critics who were expecting an award worthy script from a movie with dudes in masks portraying characters from our childhood as bloody murderers. The haters are just boring and closed minded. Grab a drink and a horror bestie and enjoy the ride. I love the shots of the forest. The pool scene is beautifully shot. I can't wait to watch the sequel. I'm so disappointed it's theatrical release was a short three days in the middle of the week. I'd be there right now if it was available anywhere for a Friday viewing.

review_title: Winnie the Pooh Blood and Honey was the best cinematic masterpiece of 2023
review_detailed_main:
Introduction: Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey is a captivating film that takes the beloved characters from A. A. Milne's classic tales and presents them in a whole new light. This imaginative and enthralling movie is a testament to the power of storytelling, showcasing the depth of emotions and the enduring bond of friendship. With its unique blend of adventure, humor, and poignant moments, Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey has left an indelible mark on the hearts of audiences worldwide.

Captivating Storyline: The film explores the idyllic Hundred Acre Wood, where Winnie the Pooh and his friends embark on a remarkable journey. Pooh and his companions find themselves facing unforeseen challenges as they set out to uncover the mysteries surrounding a missing honey harvest. What makes this story truly remarkable is its ability to balance elements of suspense, humor, and heartwarming moments.

Depth of Emotions: Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey delves into the complexities of human emotions through the endearing animal characters. It teaches us that emotions, both light-hearted and profound, shape our experiences and relationships. The movie touches upon themes of loss, resilience, and the power of friendship, allowing viewers of all ages to connect with the characters on a deeply emotional level.

Character Development: The movie not only showcases the well-loved characters from the original tales but also provides them with new layers of depth and growth. Winnie the Pooh, Tigger, Piglet, Eeyore, and the rest of the gang are beautifully portrayed, giving audiences a chance to rediscover their favorite childhood companions in a fresh and intriguing way. Each character's journey is filled with self-discovery and personal growth, making them relatable and inspiring.

Visual and Musical Delight: The animation in Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey is breathtaking. The Hundred Acre Wood is brought to life with stunning attention to detail, capturing the whimsical charm of the original stories while adding a touch of mystery. The musical score perfectly complements the narrative, creating an immersive experience that tugs at the heartstrings and transports viewers into the enchanting world of Pooh and his friends.

Timeless Life Lessons: Underneath its charming exterior, Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey imparts valuable life lessons. It emphasizes the importance of perseverance, empathy, and the strength that lies within friendship. The film reminds us of the beauty of simplicity and the significance of cherishing the small joys in life. Through the characters' triumphs and setbacks, we learn profound truths about resilience and the power of love.

Conclusion: Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey is an exceptional movie that captivates audiences with its intriguing storyline, depth of emotions, and unforgettable characters. It has successfully reinvented the beloved world of Winnie the Pooh while retaining the core elements that make these characters so beloved. This remarkable film takes viewers on a heartfelt journey, leaving an indelible mark on their hearts and reminding them of the enduring power of friendship and love. Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey is a testament to the magic of storytelling, making it an incredible cinematic experience that should not be missed. WINNIE THE POOH BLOOD AND HONEY 2 IS COMING TO EAT Y'ALL SOUL!!

I'm not sure what people expected from Winnie the Pooh: Blood and Honey. I mean, it's a slasher film about a twisted version of Pooh, so why were people expecting something different? Critics have been harsh, and honestly, I don't get why. Trust me, I was one of the first to think this movie would be terrible, but after finally watching it a year after its release, I was pleasantly surprised. While it's far from perfect, the movie does a lot of things right.

One thing I really appreciated about Blood and Honey is that it doesn't waste time with unnecessary details. The filmmakers committed to their wild idea and took it as far as they could. It's clear they knew exactly what kind of movie they wanted to make.

I guess some people expected to hear Winnie the Pooh talking like in the cartoons, but I'm glad they decided to keep the "monsters" silent. It adds a creepy element to their personalities and enhances the horror aspect. For a concept that many thought was stupid, they managed to create something fun and engaging. If you enjoy slasher films, you'll probably have a good time with this one. Sure, there's gore-plenty of it-but what did you expect from a film called Blood and Honey?

What I really liked was the break from typical slasher clichés. Instead of the usual teens having sex before the killing spree, we get a group of women on a quiet retreat. It works well, and the change of setting adds something fresh to the genre. The actresses give decent performances-not amazing, but definitely good enough for a movie like this.

I also loved the ending. It was bold and didn't follow the cowardly, safe choices we often see in horror movies.

So, if you're into slashers, don't let the harsh 2/10 reviews turn you away. That rating makes no sense. I've seen films that deserve less than zero, and Blood and Honey is far from that.

It was such a compelling and thought provoking movie. It was such a funny and deep movie about being yourself. It has made me want to take cocaine to experience it again in all its epic ness. I could not recommend this movie enough the Winnie the Pooh goes through so much character development!!!! The actors including Natasha tosini Amber toig Thorne Craig david doisett Natasha Rose mills and Richard d myers were very impressive and while kid actors are usually the weak point in movies this one was one of its strongest points. The constumes were beautiful I even forgot that the bear was costume half the time.

I just finished watching Pooh and I've got to say I absolutely love it. I loved seeing a different take on poo it was very fresh and new. Everything was perfect to the acting, story telling, gore, etc. The cinematography was perfect and terrifying at the same time! I'm amazed at what they can do on such a low budget. We always see a loving poo but what if he went bad??? This story tells that and so much more the Poo and Christopher Robin dynamic is so good and compelling it will make you wonder what happens next!!! I encourage everyone to go watch this masterpiece and please give it a try regardless of what the critics think.

I went into this knowing it was a B movie with a controversial premise...we were not disappointed. The storyline was interesting, the acting wasn't bad (Definitely seen much worse in B horror during early 2000s, yikes!) The characters basically reacted in ways that made sense, i.e. Turning on lights, acquiring weapons, looking for phones, etc. Only a couple of scenes where we felt as if they were the typical dumb horror movie stereotypes. The cinematography was excellent. Some movement shots were a bit dicey but the angles were great so maybe with a bit more money or time those could be perfected? Gore was well done without being overly gratuitous; super gross when necessary and yet not buckets of blood just for the sake of it. Not a ton of jump scares but a nice amount of the stalker vibe shots, especially the hot tub scene.

This was a fun,stupid,slasher, gross out, movie.

It's a really not bad WHY NOT kind of movie.

I just read about the budget. The special effect gore was good and Zany! The costumes I thought did it Justice. They figured out how to crossover the evil animal with human characters. It was senseless. Which brings me back to the why not. It was so ridiculously far fetched fantasy story book twist on something loveable. It was devilish in comparison to adorable. It had some classic moments where the evil plays a little soft for a moment but then recalls the real mission. If you enjoy a well done rarity of gore. Go ahead.

Winnie the Pooh blood and honey" is a horror movie that will keep you on the edge of your seat. The movie's strong point is its masterful use of suspense and tension.

.

The jump scares are also well-executed, with sudden bursts of violence that will make you jump out of your seat.

The acting in the movie is excellent for a budget film. They bring a sense of authenticity to their roles, making the movie feel like a true story rather than a work of fiction.

The cinematography and visual effects in the movie are also impressive. The scenes set in the dark and creepy forest are particularly effective, creating a claustrophobic and unsettling atmosphere.

Overall, "Winnie the Pooh Blood and Honey" is a well-crafted horror movie that delivers on both scares and story. If you're a fan of the horror genre, this movie is definitely worth a watch. However, if you're sensitive to graphic and violent content, it may not be suitable for you.

review_title: Lots Of Blood, Not Much Honey

review_detailed_main:
I did not go into this expecting much but was pleasantly surprised with an actual plot and good story telling.

I can only assume the bad reviews are based on costume design. The actors all played their parts well and the flow of the movie was at just the right pace.

I would not recommend for kids as the killing is extremely brutal with little to no hesitation on the killers part. I told my own children this movie will give them nightmares.

Overall I think it was really well done and may watch again in the future. The brutality alone should put goosebumps on your arm or be the reason somebody holds onto you more tightly.

review_title: From what i heard, i was expecting terrible. But its ...alright for what it is?
review_detailed_main:
I heard about this movie last year and some peoples saying it was one of the worst movie ever made and such. I really don't understand where these critics come from.

Number three on my Halloween watchlist this year, i was in the mood for something short that i could turn my brain off and just have a quick fun, and i got it with this.

Like sure, its not without faults. For instance the concept of the characters is barely used and for 95% of the movie, it could had been any generic slasher monsters and it would had done the same thing. None of the human characters were particulary developed or made me care much for them either.

But for 100 000$ this movie had some very decent kills, and ultimately thats what you want in a slasher movie before anything else... Not every kills landed. Some were "off camera" probably to reduce cost, but some were very solid.

I don't think any of the special effects were bad per say. Maybe at times the camera was a bit shaky and sure its not the best direction i ever saw, but for a 100 000$ b-slasher, i think it was more than alright.

Overall i enjoyed my 90 minutes watching this. Will it become a cult classic for me? Absolutely not. But it surely do not deserve the hate it got.

I try to keep one movie per franchise per year in my halloween watchlist so i will likely wait til next year to watch the sequel, but its one im interest to see.

Peoples had just too high expectations. I assume they either wanted a complete spoof/delirium movie, or something that looked like it was made with 20 millions. This is neither of it. Its threaten as a regular slasher with seriousness, it has its fair share of blood and gore, and its done on a very small budget. Take it or leave it.

review_title: Yeah, I'm one of those weird people.
review_detailed_main:
When this movie was first announced, I was unironically excited to see it. First off, I am a massive fan of the world of Winnie the Pooh and his friends, I've watched the movies and episodes of different TV shows. Second, I was interestee in the idea of seeing Winnie the Pooh as a horror villain. Now don't get me wrong, this is a horrible movie in every aspect of filmmaking, but this is one of those movies I unironically loved when I first watched it back in 2023.

Positives for Winnie-the-Pooh: Blood and Honey (2023): First off, I have to give props to Rhys Frake-Waterfield for actually making this movie happen in the first place because not many filmmakers are given the chance to make the movies they want to make. This movie was fun to watch. I am also very impressed with how Rhys Frake-Waterfield actually got to film the movie in the location of the actual Hundred Acre Woods. And finally, there are some decent kills in the movie.

Negatives for Winnie-the-Pooh: Blood and Honey (2023): This movie was made on a cheap budget and it shows in the final product. Also, there are a number of scene with CGI gore.

Overall, Winnie-the-Pooh: Blood and Honey (2023) is a horrible movie, but it's a horrible movie that I kinda had fun with.

Did this movie blow me away?? Absolutely Not.. BUT, it's literally a slasher film about a cartoon character. What do you really expect ?? It's obviously not cinematic gold, but it's fun! It's what it's meant to be!

If you're a fan of slasher movies, I'd definitely recommend. I don't get the low reviews! There must be a following of some sort, since there is now a Blood and Honey 2.

I feel like standards are way too high, considering what the film is about. I've sat through some terrible movies, that had far higher ratings than this movie.

Quality isn't bad, acting isn't superb, but makeup and the graphics, it's a solid slasher film! Give it a try!

This movie got bad reviews, but it has great potential. If you like the Jason movies from the 90's, you should give it a chance, otherwise you really won't like it. There is a reason why it made so much money. The pooh bear costume is very realistic and creepy. The characters are very life like. The movie is full of suspense gore and nudity, with a good story line starter. It basically has all the elements of a 90's horror classic, I would bet all my money that we will see many more sequels to come. Apparently the 2024 part 2 sequel is already doing very well. You should watch this before watching part 2 to give yourself some context.

review_title: Take it for what it is!!!
review_detailed_main:
Look this wasn't meant to be an amazing film. It was done super cheap super fast. However if you go into this knowing it's more funny than scary and have the popcorn ready you can definitely enjoy it! It's cheesy and gory. Dialogue leaves a lot to desire but it's fun. Something that (for us twisted minds) have always wanted to see. What happens when Christopher grows up and the gang is left to their own devices.

I think people expected too much from this. I mean seriously. It's a movie about child book characters that grow up to be cannibals. And they didn't have the budget of avengers for special effects.

One of those movies that will be remembered because it is so bad it's... Well not very good but fun to watch at least. Don't take it seriously and you won't be disappointed, you're in for a treat. The story is a bit incoherent and some parts you just have to figure out for yourself but there is allot of killing and violence. The bad masks don't help and I figure that the no-talking-bit is because the actors would have problems making themselves understood if there were any kind of dialogue. Somewhere I read that there might be a second part in the making and I hope it will be just as badgood...

I don't understand why this is getting such a low score. OK, so it's not going to win any Oscars and its not breaking new ground like perhaps The Blair Witch did (which i didn't like by the way). But you have a slasher genre horror movie with the main bad guy being a dark version of Winnie the Pooh, not the cuddly character we remember from.our childhood. Some really good bloody deaths, bit of tension and some annoying characters that i couldn't wait to be taken out. All of which is what i look for in a movie like this. I mean what were y'all expecting? It is what it is, Can't wait for the second one.

That people expected this to have interesting story and dialogues. HELLO you are watching WINNIE THE POOH BLOOD AND HONEY

This is fun, well shot, ultra-violent and atmospheric. Winnie the pooh and his friend feel like no joke villains. Story is silly, but hey, do you remember that you're watching WINNIE THE POOH BLOOD AND MAGIC on a limited budget? Id say that story is kinda charming in a way, it;s both silly and stupid but in the end, its just an excuse to make some really dark scenes fueled by excessive gore with winnie the pooh. And these are really well shot and creative. I love that the movie goes straight to it instead of pretending that it will have some well built characters and story

Im mad at people reviewing this movie. How on earth ppl love Terrifier and hate this? God bless.
